Congealed Nectar, haue more power to winne you,
Then in my dayes two veluet Petticoates,
Or an hundred acres turn'd into Taffaties.
Speake, can you doe it?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sure I thinke I can,
If need require.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: It is enough, but ſee,
What Strip • ing's this comes here? Ha? 'tis moſt happily
This is Endymion Lucius his Page.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: There's not a ſolitary walke, nor Groue
Wherein a Louer may retire himſelfe
Free from the eyes of the prophaner people,
But I haue trauers'd o're to finde my Maſter;
I haue not left a Spring vnqueſtioned,
Or any ſpreading Oake, whole quauering toppe
Is but halfe Phoebus proofe, nor can I heare
Ought of Neander his companion.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Pandora, this ſame Boy was ſent on purpoſe
Vnto this place by ſome kinde Nymph or other
Inhabiting theſe Woods in meere compaſſion
Of thee and of thy miſeries; wee could not
Haue ſtudied for a better Stale then this:
Prepare your ſelfe to faine a loue vnto him.

sp.speaker: Endym.
sp.l: But ſee Placenta, and my Maſters Loue,
I will enquire of them.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: All happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: As much to you Placenta.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And what to me?

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: What you deſerue faire Lady,
Which is aboue my wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: But Endymion,
Pri'thee ſweet Lad, let mee entreat a courteſie,
What Country-man are you?

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: What Country-man?
An Engliſh man I take it.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: An Engliſh man?
I rather thinke thou art a Ruſſian
Thou carryeſt ſuch a Winter in thy breaſt.
How canſt thou ſuffer ſuch a winning beauty
To ſtand neglected? without a ſalutation?
Goe to, you ſhame-fac'd foole, goe kiſſe her, goe.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: How kiſſe her? it does not become a ſeruant
To be ſo ſawcie with his Maſters Loue.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: It rather not becomes Endymion,
A Youth of that ſame molde and ſymetry
To be ſo baſhfull 'fore a Gentlewoman:
As for thy Maſter I diſclaime his loue
As one vnworthy.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: How? diſclaime his loue?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And with his loue, all the whole world of men,
Except 'be thee my ſoule: why flyeſt thou mee?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Come on, Come on you little frozen-nothing,
I thinke wee muſt be fayne to make you take
Your loue potion in a horne, you are ſo skittiſh.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: Nay but Placenta.— Placenta holds his hands whiles Pandora kiſſes him.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: O moſt redolent!
Aurora's ſpiced bed is not more ſweet,
Not all the odours of the early Eaſt.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: You do but mock me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How? but mock thee ſweet?
By all the Cupids in thy face, I loue thee
Beyond th' expreſſion of a womans tongue.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: This was that ſimple one that could not counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: By this ſame neſt of kiſſes I proteſt—
What would'ſt thou more?

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: More of your proteſtations.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: But canſt thou loue me then?

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: Indeed faire Lady
I doe not know, I am but newly enter'd
Into this louing trade.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: You are a Wagge:
Take her by th' hand and ſtreine it gently, ſo. —
Now kiſſe her fanne and ſigh. — Good, excellent.
(Well I haue ſeene ſome Gallants in my dayes,
Though 'twas my fortune to be married,
To that ſame lob my husband, but no matter;)
Fy on this modeſty, 'tis out of faſhion,
Giue her a greene gowne quickly, ſhee will thanke you.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: Will not as much ſattin of the ſame colour
To make her one doe as well?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Come, you'r a foole;
Downe with her, ſhee will diſcard you elſe,
As baſhfull, and vnfit for Ladies ſeruice.— [Pandora ſlips downe and pulls him after her.]

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Ay me! what meane you Sir?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Why there, why ſo;—
Oh for Neander now and Lucius
To view this ſpectacle, this would crack that great
That ſtrong and mighty bond of friendſhip, and
Make them both quarrell for her: nay Endymion,
As ſhee did pluck you downe, ſo 'tis your office
To take her vp, elſe ſhee'l forget her ſelfe
Good ſoule, and ſlumber there eternally.—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Now fie vpon you Sir, you've ſpoyl'd my linnen.
Pray Heauens no body ſaw vs: good Placenta
Reedifie what is amiſſe.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: All's well,
All's well, ſaue onely here does want a pin.
But ſtay I'le furniſh you. —
Yes, here's a knot moleſted too.—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Faire Sir,
This may ſeeme lightneſſe in mee.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Rather grauity
Who naturally tend downeward thus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: But Sir,
Let me entreat you for to entertaine
A better faith of her that is your ſeruant,
Giue it the right name Sir, and call it Loue.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: I'le call it what you pleaſe faire Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Hee neuer thinks of's Maſter: well this Boy,
Muſt wee trayne farther with vs till wee meete
With our two icy Louers. Come Pandora
Will you entreate your fayreſt Paramoure
T'accompany vs into the Groue? vvee may
Perchance there meete his Maſter, whom hee ſeekes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sweet ſhall I craue?

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: Not where you may cōmand

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: So, ſo, I'le now go plant this billing couple Exeunt Pan. Endym.
Vnder ſome pleaſant tree, which done I'le goe
And range the fields for Lucius and Neander,
And bring them to behold their cloſe embraces,
This certainely will make them hungry, and bite,
Waken their dull and ſleepy appetite,
VVee neuer prize ought truly, thinke it deare,
Vntill the time of parting does draw neare.— Exit.

div.head: The Song.
div.l: To the Ladies, Ioy, delight,
And a ſeruant that dares fight;
No neede of painting, but a face
With perpetuity of grace.
To the Lords a gracious eye
If they haue a Miſtris by.
To them both, more then all this,
Theyr Princes happineſſe, and bliſſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The day's our owne, we haue the Sun, the winde,
And all that can be call'd aduantages, beare vp.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: As I'me a Gentleman, and an elder brother—

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: St, not a word.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: You wrong me Sir, I will ſweare out my ſweare, as
I am a Gentleman I muſt, and will ſweare.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay ſweete Maſter Mungrell
Miſtake me not, I doe not goe about,
For to depriue you of that ornament,
That faſhionable quality: I but entreat you,
For to bee frugall in your language, and,
To husband your lungs; you haue an enemy
That will require them all, had you more oathes.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: How? Doe you thinke I haue no more? by my—

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: Oh, hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: Nay, you ſhall heare mee, by — Ante. ſtops his mouth.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: O, O, O.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: By my— by— my indad law.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: By my indad law, you'le ſpoyle all, why you'le ſpend
all before the time. But ſee your adverſaries are at hand.
This is their Captaine, their Conductor. Loue. Stay. Enter Loueall. and puls out his watch.
I'ue hit the very punto, this ſame minute,
Do's cut the hower into two equall portions.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You that are growne a Time-obſeruer, you
With that fine pocket Saturne in your hand;
Looke this way.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But are theſe your Champions?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: They are my Conqerours, if you pleaſe: but where are your imployments?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: They'le bee here immediately.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more. Loueall, pleaſe you to take notice
Of theſe Gentlemen, they are of ranke, and my friends.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Sweete Sir, my only wiſh is that my fortunes were but of growth, to ſhew in what degree of honour, I hold any whom you ſhall vouchſafe to call a friend. —I thirſt to know you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Doe not ſweare yet.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.l: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Sir I deſire you to pardon me, I muſt not ſweare yet, my Generall will giue the word when I muſt vent.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: 'Tis no great matter, if you throw away Cudnig • ,
Or beſwiggers, or ſome ſuch innocent oath vpon him.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: Say you ſo? [The Scholler offers to ſalute Loveall who regards him not]

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: When will he come towards me?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Sir may I know your name?

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.p: My name Sir? why Sir? I am not aſham'd of my name Sir. My name is Sir M. Mung. Sir. A poore elder brother Sir. And yet not very poore neither Sir. Heire to ſix, or ſeuen hundred a yeare Sir. My father is a Gentleman Sir. I haue an Vncle that is a Iuſtice of Peace Sir. I can borrow his white Mare when I pleaſe ſir. She ſtood him in thirty peeces ſir.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: A Mungrell Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Only be ſure you be not daſh'd.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Aſhamed of your name, ſay you? You come of a very great houſe, I'le aſſure you; I know many of the Mungrels that are able to diſpend, yeerely, more then I am willing to ſpeake of at this • ime; and which keepe their Sonnes as Gentlemanlike, at the Innes o'th Court wi • h as good cloathes on their backs, as rich belts, and as faire guilt rapiers, as the beſt Gentlemen o'the Land Sir— O well ſaid, come lift vp brauely now.

div.head: ACT. 3. SCE 2.
div.stage: Anter. Noddle-Empty. Loue. Will Wiſeacres. Hamerſhin. Mr. Mungrell.

sp.speaker: Anter.
sp.p: Tis a hundred to nothing, but theſe are they, looke to your ſtanding, and be ſure you ſuffer him to offer firſt; you haue the more advantage.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Let me alone, if I doe not vtterly confound him, let mee neuer weare good ſuite of clothes more, I haue not read the Arcadia for nothing.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Anteros, a co • pie of friends of mine.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Sir I ſhall count my ſelfe fortunate in their acquaintance; Sweete Sir— worthy Sir.

p.hi: Sans complement Mounſieur, Ie ſuis, voſtre treſhumble varlet.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: There's one of his parcels gone, he has but three more in all the world.

p.hi: Signior mio molto honorifico, per teſta del mio padre, io non he altro, advffirirui, che me ſteſſo, però fate capitale di me, è ſplendetemi per quel chio vaglio.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Do's he ſpeake French Sir?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: How thinke you Sir?

sp.speaker: Noddle.
sp.p: Nay but well I meane?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: O admirably, take heed what you doe, hee's a great Trauailer I tell you.

sp.speaker: Noddle.
sp.p: Gods mee! is he ſo? I'le not meddle with him then, I would haue tickled him elſe.

p.hi: Signior, io mi terrei ricco s' io haneſſi ſolamente le decime de i voſtri favori.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p:
Nay Sir I am not ſo well skilled in the language, as I
could wiſh I were, for your ſake, I can ſpeake a little Sir, Ʋn peu, Monſeur, tellement quellement.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: May I be ſo bo • as to beare your name Sir?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: My name is Nodale Empty Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: An Inns othe Court man Sir?

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: I haue piſt in ſome greene pots in my dayes Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Wiſ. My name is William Wiſeacres Sir. I am of a Sanguine complexion.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: In good time Sir.

sp.speaker: Wiſe.
sp.p: Very melancholy ſometimes Sir. He offers to feele him by the noſe end.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Like enough Sir

sp.speaker: Wiſe.
sp.p: Ha, he, he, he—

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, he,— O my ſides—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Gods my life! I ſhould looſe it all were my patrimony layd on't. Come on Sir, brace me your inuention to the height, you ſee your Antagoniſt.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: To him, ferret him, ferret him.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Noble Sir may I bee ſo ambitious, as to deſire my name, to be enrolled in the Catalogue of your well wiſhers.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I doe honour the very ſhadow of your ſhoe ſtrings.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Your mock'd Sir, hee weares bootes.

sp.speaker: Hamm.
sp.p: And am wholly your's cap a pea.

sp.speaker: Noddle.
sp.p: Pox on 't, I made full account, to haue had that next my ſelfe, how came hee by it trow?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What ſay you Sir?

sp.speaker: Noddle.
sp.p: I ſay Sir, that it is your beſt courſe, to take heede how you make a deed of guift of your ſelfe, for feare ſome of your friends ſuffer for it, for the Phyſnomy of your boot, tels mee, it was neuer made for you, I doe not thinke but you borrowed them.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: And I ſay Sir, that it is better to borrow then to take vpon truſt, and neuer pay, as many ſuch gallants as you doe.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Loueall, this heat is done, lets rub, and walke.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Agreed, Maſter Empty, take ſome pitty on the Scholler, let him breath a little, wilt pleaſe you walke? Lovell & Nod walke. Ant. and Ham. walke.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: I am your Seruant.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well done, 'twas ſmartly followed; but lets walke;

sp.speaker: Wiſe.
sp.p: Ha, I don't thinke ne're goe Law, but I haue ſeene you ſome where.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You're beholding to your eyes for that.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: It may be ſo.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Loueall, looke, looke, looke, another heate.

sp.speaker: VViſe.
sp.p: Don't you vſe ſometimes about Stamford ſide?

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I haue hunted, and hawked, there abouts Sir in my dayes, and beene in Sara's he • e too Sir, I was at the laſt horſe race, Sir, when Veluet-heeles, and Currants run Sir, I haue ſome reaſon to remember it, I am ſure, I was cheated of twenty peeces there, Ile ſweare vnto you Sir as I'me a Gentleman, and an elder Brother, I'me a very foole—

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Out you Nullifidian, don't let the Gentleman ſweare, tak't vpon his bare word.

sp.speaker: Wiſe.
sp.p: Nay Sir, I'le belieue you without ſwearing.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Nay but conceiue me Sir. I was a very foole (as I ſaid before) to bee drawne in after that manner, I would faine ſee the beſt cheater of them all, gull me of ſo much now.

sp.speaker: Wiſe.
sp.p: Well ſir, I deſire your better acquaintance. I haue the beſt wine in Towne for you, pleaſe you to accept.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Thanke you ſir. [They ſhake hands, he feeles him by the noſe end.]

sp.speaker: Wiſe.
sp.p: I think you & I are much vpon a complexion. He, he, he, you haue loſt your mayden-head. If it pleaſe you Sir to come to my lodging Sir, when you come to London, I ſhall thinke my ſelfe very much bound to you, I haue ſome pretty bookes there to lend you, I haue Ariſtotle's Problemes in Engliſh, and Albertus magnus de ſecretis, I, as I am a liuing ſoule.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Let's take 'em off. [They part, Lou. walkes with Wiſ. Ant. with Mun.]

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Troth Sir you haue a very neat ſuit there, I am much taken with the proportion of your hoſe, 'tis a deepe French Sir. I haue a Sattin ſuit to make ſhortly, and I would beſtow, ſome twenty dozen of gold lace vpon it, if I could but purchaſe the knowledge of ſuch a Taylour as your's, I ſhould thinke my ſelfe beholding to my Starrs for it.

sp.speaker: Ante,
sp.p: O your walking faculty, it is the only thing, now adayes your Gentlemen practiſe.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, I thinke it bee time for you to ſeeke out for a new one, for I thinke your old one will truſt you no longer.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Should you but ſee them walke in Paules, or in the Temple, with what a rauiſhing garbe—you would admire.

sp.speaker: Wiſe.
sp.p: He, he, you are ſuch a merry man, but indeed I hold that Tobacco is very good for Phlegmatick complections.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Your hilt a little forwarder; very good, your very rapier ſpeakes French; I proteſt hee ſhowes in the gracefull carriage of his legge, as though he had been a man of fourtie playes, fifteene moutings.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Nay, I ſhall doe well in time.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Gods me! you haue ſtaind your cloake ſir, how will you doe? I doubt the Gentleman that lent you it will be angry.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Thinke you ſo ſir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, there's no remedy, I muſt goe and relieue my Scholler.—Sir, a word in private, do you know that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Yes ſir, I haue read Overburies Characters; he is a ſilly fellow in blacke, I take it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well ſir, how ever you diſ-eſteeme him, I could wiſh you would take heed of him; I wonder hee did not ſtrike you all this while. Go to, I ſay no more, I hold him to be the ſtouteſt man of his hands in all this ſide o'th countrey.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Is he ſo?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why he is ſent for far and neere by the valiant of the Pariſhes, to play matches at football: I tell you hee is the onely Hammerſhin this Shire can boaſt of; not a Servingman can keep a legge or an arme whole for him, he ha's a penſion from all the Surgeons within the compaſſe of fortie miles, for breaking of bones.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Nay for my part ſir, let him be as tall a man as he will, I doe not care a 〈◊〉 for him, (doe you ſee) for I doe not meane to quarrell with him, onely I make account to jeere him a little.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, take heed, ſay I.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Nay ſir, I'le take your counſell, I'le go and fetch my rapier I left within, and then let him doe his worſt. Ex. Nod.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Follow him, follow him, the exalted muſhroome— a whorſon butterflie, he ha's nothing to jeere you for but your borrowed cloake and bootes; and I don't thinke but they bee your owne for all his talking.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: No indeed, to tell you the truth, I borrowed them of a Batchelour of our houſe, mine owne lye in limbo at a Barbers ſhop for Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But why doſt not beat him man? Gods me! beat him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Nay, I would haue bin at him, but that I was afraid—
They ſay many of 'em are very deſperate fellowes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith, to doe them right, there be many of' um that haue run through the diſcipline of a Bawdy-houſe, & learnt to quarrell there, and haue ſeene the entrailes of a Fence-ſchoole too, and in one word are ſufficiently valiant; but that proues not a generalitie. There are of them (I'le warrant you) as there are of your ſchollers, ſome that weare ſwords, only to ſcare fooles.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Nay ſir, I would haue you to know, that I am neither afraid of him, nor his ſword: but I would not willingly die yet, if I could helpe it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fear 't not man, thou ſhalt liue I warrant thee, to ſee thy good name buried before thee. Haue you nothing about you to ſtrike him with?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Yes, I haue the key of my ſtudy dore in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O nothing better then that, follow him, to him, to him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Shall I, i' faith? ſhall I?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Never ſtand, ſhall I? ſhall I? but doe 't.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Ne're goe, and ſo I will: Ile teach him to abuſe any of our cloath againe. Exit Ham. He whiſpers him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: St, Mr Mungrell.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: As I'm a Gentleman, and an elder brother—

div.stage: He runs after them offring to draw.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: But how now Anteros? what buſineſſe is this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Can you but hold your peace, and follow them
With your ſweet William? nay, but will you goe? Ex. Loue. & William
You'l looſe the banquet if not preſently.

sp.speaker: Anter.
sp.l: O, O. —
Would I could looſe my ſelfe, become a Mouſe,
Or flie, that I might find a cabbin here,
To hide my ſelfe from theſe ſame women. O, — He climbes the tree.
But I will climbe this tree—

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I wonder much
Where our two loving friends ſhould lye ſo cloſe;
There's not a place where they doe uſe, but wee
Haue viſited this morning. I doe long
To giue them this moſt pleaſing ſpectacle:
But I will now ſearch the Iuſtice his houſe,
Perchance they may be there.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Another kiſſe; loe thus I will revenge She kiſſes Endym.
My ſelfe on thoſe two frozen Lovers; thus,
And thus, and thus — Revenge, how ſweet thou art
Vnto a woman!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O — I am afrayd
They will offend, commit, commit before mee.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And canſt thou loue me, ſweet Endymion?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Behold a taſt what I can doe.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Theſe kiſſes He kiſſes her Redit in ſcenā Pla.
Haue not that maſculine relliſh yet me thinks,
Which I enjoy'd in the manly embraces
Of Lucius, or Neander.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: It is ſtrange,
Not one about this houſe that can inſtruct mee
What ſhould become of them, I wonder at it;
But I am glad that Conſtantina's flight
Is not ſuſpected yet, ſo well that Boy
Doe's perſonate her.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Are they not there Placenta?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: St; No. O yes your Vncle is at home.
It will not yet bee dinner time this houre;
You may embrace another walke.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Content;
Endymion, wil't pleaſe you t' accompany us? Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why ſo then— What againe?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: You'l leaue your blubbering, Minion, come your waies.
You ſet your minde on ſuch a man? yet more?
You might as well bee in loue with that ſame Sunne,
And ſhould as ſoone enjoy it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He ſpeakes high,
Pray heavens hee does not looke ſo high, for feare
He ſhould deſcrie me.

sp.speaker: Vrſe.
sp.l: Father, I cannot laſt
Out two dayes longer without Anteros.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How's that? now all my ſtarres be mercifull!
It is a viſion ſure, this cannot bee.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Come, you'r a fooliſh girle, he marry you?
That day that hee does marry you, will I
Bring backe to life all that were dead before
The univerſall Deluge.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, Ile helpe
You with a farre better expreſſion, ſir,
That day that hee does marry her, ſhall you
Become an honeſt man; a harder Province
Then to bring all the dead, to life againe.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: There are a hundred reaſons (daughter) why
You ſhould not hope it, firſt hee hates all women,
Next if he did not, you that are deform'd,
Lame, and miſhapen, blacke, beſides, ill manner'd.—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: (Hee does not ſee the wallet on her back.)
Haue the leſt cauſe to hope.

sp.speaker: Vrſ.
sp.l: But there are (father)
Sixe hundred reaſons, why I ſhould loue him.
His manly carriage, his full breaſts, his hayre,
And his fine cloathes, his golden breeches, and—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: His traiterous noſe: I, I, 'tis that I know,
'Tis like the Ivy-buſh vnto a Taverne,
Which tells vs there is Wine within; but I
Will take an order with you Sir e're long,
And haue you par'd.

sp.speaker: Vrſ.
sp.l: Well I will neuer leaue
My crying (that's reſolu'd) vntill I ſee him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O! Could I commit a crime e're I was made,
'Gainſt nature worthy ſuch a puniſhment?
It is decreed, I will vnman my ſelfe, immediately.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: What ſhall I doe? tis ſtrange—
Well, 't muſt be ſo: I will goe ſeeke Terpander,
And mooue him to this match: moſt of his lands
I haue in mortgage, nay indeed they are
Forfeited to me, for the day is paſt
Wherein hee was bound to pay in the money,
The' advantage of this forfeiture, will I
Threaten to take, vnleſſe hee does compell,
His ſonne to take my daughter, to his wife.
Nay, rather then I will bee diſappointed,
Hee for a portion, ſhall haue in his bonds,
Come daughter, bee of comfort, wee will goe
Directly to Terpander, where I'le vſe
Such arguments, as ſhall enforce him make
His ſonne both loue, and marry you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Like enough.
'Tis very likely Sir, but that this tree
Does not afford any ſuch fruit, I'd throw He comes downe.
An old ſhooe after you,—ſuch arguments
As ſhall enforce him make his ſonne, both loue,
And marry you—well how his pills may worke
Which the old man, I know not: for my ſelfe
I will prouide a quicke deliuerance.
VVhy ſheepheard? Stipes? [tic toc:] now I muſt, and will
Goe forward in this plot, of my diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: VVhat make you there?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: VVhy nothing Iacke.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Come on, you are a fine fellow, to go and ſet them together by the eares thus, are you not?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But haue they done it finely?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Finely doe you call it? why your Scholler ha's ſo mauld Mr. Noddle with the key of his ſtudy dore, made ſuch a breach in his Pericranium, that without queſtion all his French ends haue taken their flight, through that paſſage; as for my coſen Mr. William, hee's crept into an old hole, behind the hangings, that in the dayes of old, h'as beene the Aſylum, for decayed bootes, and ſhooes out of date, and there lyes hee, all alone, very melancholy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he, but how was my Gentleman, and my elder brother imploy'd all this while?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: As Gentlemen vſe now adayes, in ſwearing; when he ſaw that hee could not draw his ſword, hee ran vp and downe the roome, and meaſured out the time of the combat with oathes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Death! that I had but ſeene this.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: VVould thou had'ſt: for I haue e'ene taken a ſurfer of them. I pray thee let's inuent ſome way, or other
For to bee rid of them, canſt thou not thinke?
Thinke, thinke, man — thinke— which I'le effect, vnleſſe
All that is called Fortune, doth forſake mee.
See'ſt thou that brace of Cabbins, on each ſide
My Vncle's houſe?

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: They'r Dog-kennels I take it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: They are, no more, but ſee they come, I'le ſlip
Aſide leſt I bee ſeene.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I wonder what
His brayne is now ſo hot in travaile with.

div.head: ACT. 3. SCE. 6.
div.stage: Ant. Love. Wiſe. Noddle Empty, with his head, and face all bloody.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Lend mee your hankercher, if you haue one about you Coſen, mine ha's not a dry place in it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What doe you bleede Mr. Noddle?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Yes Sir a little wild blood, hold that Coſen, vn peu Mounſieur.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Did not you tell mee, all his French ends were gone? vn peu will not forſake him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: A whorſon cowardly ſlaue, to ſtrike a man e're one was aware of him, and to giue one no time, to draw his rapier—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: S'me, 'tis ſomewhat deepe I doubt.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Nothing by Hercules Sir, a ſcratch, a ſcratch, well I'le ſay nothing, but by this good blood, that runns—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith if you had done as that good blood does, Mr. Noddle, it had beene better for you.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: No Sir, I ſcorne it, I am not of that ſtraine i'faith, and that hee ſhall know, the ſempiternall raſcall.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come on Mr. Wiſeacres, I belieue you and your Kinſeman are much of a complexion.

sp.speaker: Wiſe.
sp.p: I am very melancholy at this time.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I but you muſt take heed of theſe fits, they'l ſpoyle you, I heard ſay, that you crept into a priuate, retir'd roome e'ne now, and there converſ'd with ſpiders and crickets, fye vpon it, you muſt labour againſt that humour; but indeed me thinks your Coſen is of a very deepe ſanguine.

sp.speaker: Wiſe.
sp.p: Ha, he, you are ſuch a witty man.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Coſen? Yes I am much beholding to my Coſen; I might haue beene kild for him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, come, I like him well for it, the Gentleman does weigh how much the Republ. might bee impeached, by the loſſe of a man.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p:
Republi
que ? Repuddingpy. By this light, a man is little better then mad, that will keepe company with ſuch ſnow-heapes, ſuch white-liverd, counterfied lackdawes—but all's one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I, I betwixt friends, and kinſemen; ye two are all one I know. Your Coſen is very cholerick now.

sp.speaker: Wiſe.
sp.p: I but I am very ſeldome ſo, for Albertus Magnus faith — [Loveall as though he came from his Vncles.]

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Now the good Gods! where ſhall I find theſe moſt vnfortunate Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why how now Iacke? what inauſpicious wind
Ha's rayſ'd this cloudy weather in thy face?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: O Anteros, wee are vndone, vndone;
I'le haue this day weare black ith' Calender,
That after ages may beware of it,
It is ſo full of Omen —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Whats the matter? I pray thee ſpeake. Hee faines to heare ſome body comming.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: O they bee here, — who's there?
Pray heauens it bee not the Conſtables officious induſtry: how will you doe Sir? You haue ſlaine the Scholler.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: I would I had elſe.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Nay Sir, this is neither time nor place for ſuch idle wiſhes, here ha's beene a Surgeon already, that liues hard by, and his ſentence is, that hee cannot liue aboue two howers, hee ſwounded ſix times ſince you left him, it ſeemes you bruiſed him ſo with falling on him, with the hilt of your rapier, that hee bleeds inward — I know not what to ſay to it— I was bewitch'd I thinke, nay thinke, thinke, thinke what courſe you will take, you muſt bee ſuddaine, the officers are ſent for to apprehend you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is this in ieſt (I wonder) or in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Is he ſo indeed? I pray you tell mee true Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why, what doe you take mee to bee Sir? haue I this for my loue, and care of your ſafety? as you ſowed, ſo reape for mee; I hope you will belieue your owne ſences, I thinke I ſee the officers comming.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: 'Sme! what ſhall I doe? Mr. Loveall, nay good Sir, I doe belieue you, I know not which way to take.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Nay there's no ſtirring that way, you'l meet them in the teeth.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: What if I goe through the backe dore, and take horſe?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: They'l meet you that way too.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Any thing, good Sir, I beſeech you, looke the dore goes, I proteſt twenty Serieants could not haue ſtrucke ſuch a feare into me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, will you truſt your fortunes into my hands?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: And liues ſweet Sir.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Quickly then enter heere, I'le ſhut you in untill the ſearch bee paſt: nay will you in? who's there? immediately, good Maſter William. He ſhuts Nod. into one of them.

sp.speaker: Wiſe.
sp.p: Nay ſir, I'le go to my horſe if there were twenty Conſtables, they haue nothing to doe with mee, for I am ſure I did not ſtrike a blow, no as I'm a living ſoule. —

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Gods mee, what will you doe? were not you in the company with him? that makes you acceſſary; haue you read ſo much law, and know not that? nay, will you in?— Ha, ha, he.

div.stage: He puts him into the other.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: What ſai'ſt thou now my Anteros?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What ſay I?
I ſay thou art an arch-diſſembler,
A workman in the trade: By all that's good,
I ſhould haue been thus gull'd my ſelfe, thou didſt
So ſmoothely act it, with ſuch paſſion,
And anger at their incredulitie.
I was afraid thou would'ſt haue beat the foole,
Becauſe he would not let himſelfe be gull'd
So ſoone as thou wouldſt haue him, but ſtay now—
How ſhall we dreſſe our other brace?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: That province
Is yours; as for mine owne, you ſee I haue
Provided for them, and conveniently:
Yet if you will embrace my counſell, write
After the copie I haue ſet you, doe,
Behold a patterne, and ſee (happily)
A cheſt where Stipes in the dayes of old
Ha's kept tame Conies, now uninhabited.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Right, but I feare, 'tis not capacious
Enough for both.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing, looke you here,
See you that fine ſpruce new erected hogſtie
On the other ſide of Stipes houſe?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I doe.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: And doe you ſee it may be pinn'd without?
Hiſt, eaſily, ſoftly, I'le fill up the time They enter.
With ſome diſcourſe, till you haue fram'd your count'nance.

div.head: ACT. 3. SCEN. 8.
div.stage: Love. Ante. Mr. Mung. Sir Hammer.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Wu'd I might ne're ſtirre Mr. Mungrell, if I care a pin for a hundred ſuch, an Inns oth' Court man quoth a? nere goe, I thinke they learne nothing there, but how to ſwagger, and bee proud.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Nay Sir, now I muſt chide you, will you accuſe all, for the default of ſome particulars? by the ſame reaſon, I'le conclude, that all yee Schollers, are coxecombes, becauſe I ſee one that is ſo.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Meaning mee Sir?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Meaning you Sir? pardon mee 'tis meere iniuſtice in you, I'le aſſure you Sir, this whole realme, yeelds not better qualified Gentlemen, and more gentilely parted, then many of them are, and to whom, the common weale is more indebted.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Becauſe hee has got a good ſuit of cloathes vpon his backe (I'le bee hang'd if they bee pay'd for yet) and a ring in 's band ſtring, to play withall when he wants diſcourſe, he thinkes hee may carry the ball on 's toe before him, and that no man muſt dare to meet him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No more Scholler, you haue met with him ſufficiently, why Anteros, when? and here's a braue Pylades too, that would not ſee his Oreſtes oppreſt by multitude. [Hee claps him on the backe.]

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Arreſt mee Sir? ſoft, and eaſily Sir, more words to a bargaine; s'duds! I thinke my ſword be mortil'd into a ſnayle, [Hee flyes backe and offers to draw] I cannot entreate him out of his ſhell. Arreſt mee Sir? As I'm a Gentleman, and an elder brother, I owe no man a farthing that I meane to pay him. Nay come Sir, I am fleſh'd now i'ſaith.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You will not quarrell with your friends Sir, will you?

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Friends Sir? I know not whether you be my friend, or no; I am ſure you vſe no friendly language.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pri'thee Scholler, tayle off Mr. Mungrell a little, hee'l never leaue now hee has drawne blood once.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Come, you'r a foole; the Gentleman's of worth, and our friend.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.p: Nay I haue done now, I did but try how I could quarrell a little.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Faith Sir, this would haue made a faire ſhow in a Country Ale-houſe.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Nay Sir, as ſoone as my father dyes, (which will not bee long I hope, for hee lyes ſicke now) I'le goe to Londorn, and learne to quarrell there, for a yeare or two, and then come downe againe, and practiſe amongſt my Tenants.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why Anteros; pray thee releiue mee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: St, not a word, for a million of worlds. Harke you Scholler. [Hee whiſpers with the Scholler.]

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: I hope you are not angry?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Angry old Bully? hee had a hard heart, that would be angry with thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis as I tell you, his wound ha's beene ſearch'd by a very skilfull Surgeon, and his Pia mater is found to be periſhed, and when that's gone, you know there is ſmall hope.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: None at all Sir, I've read it in Magirus, Cozen Mungrell, come hither quickly —

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Now, now, how greedily the Scholler ſucks it in.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: What's the matter? but is this true?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: As true as you'r a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Hee never emptyed a buttry pot after a match at footeball, with greater appetite, then hee devours this gullery.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Take heed what you doe, the leaſt protraction is full of danger.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: O the Lord! what will become of vs?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Loveall ſtirre the doore a little — paſſion O mee! there's ſome body at the dore, looke, looke, creepe into this cheſt, I'le ſhut you in. He ſhuts vp the Scholler.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Any where good Sir.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.p: Where will you hide me ſir? I'le goe into the cheſt too.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Here's hardly roome enough for my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay, ſtay. In good ſooth Mr. Conſtable here's no ſuch men this way— what ſay you, you three-penny cracke crowne? I tell you, they haue already taken horſe. Here, here, here, creepe in, ſtoope man, ſtoope. [He ſhuts Mun. into the hogſty.]

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he.
Why ſo, wee'r now at Liberty, farewell.
My ſiſters wrongs, and ſorrowes call for mee,
And ſhall be anſwered.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well adiew ſweet Sir. Exit.
I muſt bee ſuddaine, or l'me loſt for euer. [tic. toc.]
By this time ſure my father melts (why ſheepherd.)
The ample benefit, that ſhall acrew
Vnto him by this worthy match, this inſtant
Arriues at 's weather-beaten apprehenſion;
(I doe but know it, am but ſure of it)
O, what a dainty pleaſant thing it is
For to bee free from care! to ſleepe a night,
Without the dreaming of a Creditour,
Or the diſturbance of that gobling Forfeit!
It cannot but be ſo, vpon my ſoule,
Hee trades in this ſame cogitation,
This very minute — Stipes. che ti venga l' cancro.
Well, if hee be aboue ground, I will find him,
Or looſe my ſelfe, I'le ſeeke him in the paſtures. Exit.

div.head: The Song, ſung by two Trebles.

sp.speaker: 1. Treb.
sp.l: But why
Doe the wing'd minutes flie
ſo fast away?
Stop your courſe yee haſtie howers,
And ſollicite all the powers
to let you ſtay.
For the earth could ne're ſhew forth
An object of a greater worth.

sp.speaker: 2. Treb.
sp.l: But why
Doe the wing'd minutes flie
ſo fast away?

sp.speaker: 1. Treb.
sp.l: It is becauſe that they which follow,
Crowd on to haue a ſight as well as they;

sp.speaker: 2. Treb.
sp.l: Harke how the ghoſts of paſſed moments groane,
'cauſe they are gone:
And rayle at Fate,
And curſe the date
Of their ſhort liues expir'd ſo ſoone.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Then ſtop your courſe, you haſtie howers,
And ſollicit all the powers
to let you ſtay,
For the earth could ne're ſhew forth
An object of a greater worth.

div.head: ACTVS 4. SCENA 1.
div.l: Ha, ha, he,
I haue diſcovered more then e're Columbus,
Or our owne water-fowle, Drake: my pretty ſtripling,
Which I did take away from Stipes even now,
Is prov'd a woman, prov'd an errant Lady,
That is in queſt after her errant Knight,
Who is enchanted. 'Tis the Neece (forſooth)
Of our good vertuous Iustice, Mr Hooke,
Who has put on this habit for to follow
Her lover Cleopes, who has forſooke her.
All this did ſhee confeſſe to mee in private,
'Soone as ſhe ſaw I had deſcry'd her ſex
And name; but I haue ſtayd her pilgrimage,
Shee's faſt enough, I warrant her, i'th nooſe
Of wedlocke now, to ſtirre in haſte. No ſooner
Did I reade woman in her lookes, but ſtraight
I did command my mayds for to unpage her,
And cooke her in her kind, in her owne ſawce;
Shee's pickeld now in ſome three yards of lawne:
Here ſhee has it, and there ſhee has it, fie, fie.
Was I a young man now againe, and ſhould
Venture on ſuch a diſh to carue, by'r Lady,
I ſhould not know which ſide for to begin on:
Hardly diſtinguiſh breaſt from backe. Well, well,—
Beſhrew my heart the queanes, where e're they had them,
Haue hung good rags about her; ſure they borrow'd them.
This being done, I went unto Neander,
Told him, that I had got a Boy, and dreſt him
Fit for his palate: he rejoyc'd, made haſte
Vnto the contract, and (as kind Fortune would)
That very time a good old merry Vicar
Of my acquaintance came to viſite me.
I crav'd his ayd, and (in one word) I brought her
Vayl'd, but firſt ſoftned by a thouſand threatnings,
If ſhee but mov'd towards a diſcovery.
The good kinde Gentleman thinking her boy,
And therefore in his power when er'e he pleaſe
For to untie the knot, is before witneſſe,
Contracted to her by the Vicar.— Oh for Lucius now.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: See where hee comes; but yet how heavily!
How full of earth mee thinks his paces bee!
Hee lookes as though his teeth had playd this fortnight,
Kept Holyday. But I'le accoſt him.—Lucius.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The Gods befriend thee, whoſoe're thou art,
That I am thought worth naming yet, not loſt
Vnto all mankinde quite, though to my ſelfe!

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: Theſe words doe ſavour of too much diſtractio'n.
You muſt take comfort ſir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Who 's that dares talke
Of comfort to me? But once name the word
That is exil'd whole Nature? good Mr Liuely
Waſt you that ſpoke?

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: It was, and I muſt haue you
Remoue this ſame December from your lookes:
I come to make you happy.

sp.speaker: Luc,
sp.l: Thou art come
To looſe thy labour then; I am below
Both all the loue, and all the ſpight of Fortune,
Shee will not make mee happy, and ſhee cannot
Make mee more wretched then I am. I lye,
Shee may doe both. But ſpeake thou reverend head,
Has ought that 's good befallen my Neander,
That thou dar'ſt venture out that name of happy
So confidently upon me? —ſay.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: There has,
But more to you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Good, happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How? happineſſe to me? thou ſhould'ſt haue put
The ſpace of fifteene ages 'twixt thoſe words,
They are ſo farre from reconciliation;
Thou haſt no Grammar in thee, know'ſt no concord.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: But I haue Muſicke in me, and that's better.
I'le make thee daunce my ſolitary one.
Pandora ſhall be thine to day.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How? mine to day?

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: Thy wife, thy ſelfe, but in another character.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Vnſpeak't againe, it muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: It muſt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Doeſt thou intend to buy me to thee? and
To breake me and my fortunes with a courteſie,
Which I ſhall ne're be able to repay?
Imploy thy art then, all thy quicker plots
To further my Neander in his loue:
Who by how much the more his vertues be
Greater then mine (who hardly haue ſo much
As will redeeme me from the name of vicious)
So much the more will apprehend the benefit,
So much the more reward thee.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Speak no further,
Pandora's thine, ſhee's thine, thine owne, beleeu't.
Hee is already married to another.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: I doe confeſſe that I am ſomething fallen
Oft from that height of reaſon which before,
While I had libertie, I did enjoy:
But thou do'ſt wrong me much, if thou do'ſt thinke
That Loue has eaten up all man in mee.
I tell you, I doe know your plots, your drifts,
And all your conſultations, as well
As if I had had a cabbin in your boſome,
And had from thence betrayd them; did not I
Heare when Neander did ſollicite thee
For to procure a Maſculine Bride for him?
Did not I heare thee promiſe him to doe it?
Haſt thou not now perform'd it? are not they
By thy procurement now contracted? ſpeake;
'Tis not ſo eaſie to deceiue the eyes
Of Loue, how e're our franticke Poets ſay
He feeds on nought but Lolium.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: As I doe hope to liue, as I doe prize
My lungs, my breath, laughter, and ſacke, (beleeue me)
I haue Neander faſt, hee 's married
To one that is as truely woman, as
Was ſhe that did produce thee, and becauſe
You ſhall be certaine of 't, 'tis Conſtantina.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But canſt thou utter this (without a bluſh?)
Or hath thy many yeeres
Block'd up thoſe channels of thy blood, that now
They are not able to afford that face,
(That ſtarved face of thine, bankrupt of vertue)
The leaſt reliefe? but I'le undoe your plots.
Since you doe force me, I'le confeſſe a ſecret,
Which hitherto I'ue hardly whiſpered
Vnto my privat'ſt thoughts. I am no husband,
No husband (marke you) for Pandora, nor
For any woman living; for kind Nature
Has ſtamped Eunuch on mee from my cradle.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: What do I heare?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That wch is true.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: An Eunuch!

div.head: ACT. 4. SCEN. 3.
div.stage: Liuely, Neander, Conſtantina velat â facie, Lucius.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: But ſee Neander comes with his new Bride.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Why doe you weepe and ſigh ſo boy? no more.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Doe you heare that?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: But ſee my Lucius.
I muſt quite alter my diſcourſe, my garbe,
And all my actions. Hence dull melancholly,
I now muſt finde a face that muſt out-ſmile
A morne in Iune. Lucius, a thouſand hayles.

sp.speaker: Conſtan.
sp.l: Vnhappy Conſtantina! to whom Fate
Neither permits to liue, nor yet to die.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Break off thoſe ſighs you peeviſh girle, or i'le — not yet?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: What meanes this ſtrange and ponderous eye?
As though you were to take our Altitudes
Lucius? what? and doe you ſmile? faith ſpeake.
How doeſt thou like my Choyce? perhaps you wonder
At this ſo ſudden match; but (Friend) you ſee
What Love and a faire Gentlewoman can doe.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: I am the boldeſt wretch aliue. It cannot,
Cannot be long before he needs muſt know her.
What will become of thee then Liuely? ha?
You muſt be ſure not to unvaile him Sir,
The boy would not be knowne.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: What muſe you on
So deepely Lucius? does your firſt ſonnes name
You ſhall beget on the moſt faire Pandora
Perplex you now? come on, I'le anſwer for you,
He ſhall be called Fortunate.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Not ſo,
Rather that name belongs to you Neander,
That ſhall haue no ſuch care to trouble you:
For if my art deceiues me not (faire creature
Your hand) this wife of yours is never likely
For to beare children, but on her backe, or armes.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Why pray thee ſweet?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Cauſe in this little vale
That lies at the foot of Venus mountaine, here,
I doe diſcover ſomething too much for mother.
Come, come, Neander, theſe are poore devices,
Trickes of the Scene, and ſtale, they will not take.
And you gray haires, me thinks that thou ſhouldſt owe
A greater and more filiall reverence
To the faire Ceremonies of the Church, then thus
To ſtalke with them, to make them ſtales unto
Such baſe ridiculous—

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: Lucius, doe but heare.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I will not heare thee.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: Here's a benefit
Plac'd moſt deſervingly! I doe not like it.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: I do not apprehend him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A faire gowne
Indeed, and ſope, and ſtarch enough, to dazle
The eyes of ſome young countrey heire, that has
Never been drill'd through Drury lane, or Bloomsbury.
But 'pray thee (friend) whoſe daughter haſt thou married?
What may ſhe haue to name?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: What ſhall I anſwer?
I am i'th bryers.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: Tell him 'tis Conſtantina
Our Iuſtices Neece.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Moſt excellent diſſembler!
As though you know not Conſtantina ſir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But is this Conſtantina?

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: 'Tis truer;
Somewhat then you doe beleeue it is.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Is this
Iacke Loveall's ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: 'Tis.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But is this ſhee
Whom Cleopes once lov'd, and has forſaken?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: O me! why doe I liue and heare that name?

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: Did you not mark that ſigh? how ſmartly't came?
No, no, I haue not fitted you, I haue not.
'Tis a young Roſcius I tell you. No ſooner
Was Cleopes nam'd, but the arch-villaine ſigh'd,
As if it had been truely Conſtantina.
I doe not like this buſineſſe yet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Is this
That cryed up wonder? that Fidelia?
A ſodaine change.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Yet at the laſt? 'tis well, I'le giue the word
Vnto Pandora: but with ſpeciall care
That the boy knowes not of his Maſters preſence.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: What buſineſſe is't that this ſame Midwifes face
Does fetch and carry thus about I wonder?
Hy, ſhee appeares againe.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: All health old man.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Old? and how old? but what's the newes that you
Are rig'd with now? and whither bound I pray you?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Next to that loving payre of friends, whoſe ſorrowes
I haue lamented oft, and amongſt which
I iudge it not the leaſt, that while yee two
Diſcourſe in ſighes, and teares, that wanton mayde
That is the cauſe of all your heauineſſe,
Laſciuiouſly does ſport herſelfe, and melts
In the embraces of an other.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Regardles of your woes, or her owne honour.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Now all the Gods! where is he?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Woman ſpeake,
What is hee for a man?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: I know him not,
So farre as to his name; but this mine eyes
Dare witneſſe, tis a compoſition
Of blood and ſpirits not to be deſpis'd.
A feature able enough to tempt; beſides—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Neander, whil'ſt wee ſtriue about the ſhaddow
Wee haue the ſubſtance raviſh'd from vs.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Ha?
It cannot bee, 'tas noe affinitie
With truth; It muſt not bee belieu'd good Lucius.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Can yee retyre your ſelues vnder this tree
A little, and expect? but e're I goe,
Yee ſhall both promiſe as yee'r Gentlemen
To endure the ſight with patience.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Wee will.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: It is enough.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But does this woman gull vs? Exit Plac.
Or is it reall think'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Harke.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No more.

div.head: ACT. 4. SCE 5.
div.stage: Placenta. Lucius. Pandora. Neander, Endymion. Liuely. Conſtantina

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Can yee belieue it yet? are your eyes yet
Inſtructed?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Tis my boy Endymion,
Now hell and tortures!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Were all odours loſt,
And beggered Nature had not ſweetes enough
T' embalme the dying Phoenix left, from hence
From this ſame lip, Shee might reſtore her ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Ah Lucius! muſt he not dye?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is a ſacriledge vnpardonable
To pluck him from that Altar.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Once more ſweet—
Two pendant Cherryes when ſome gentle gale
Makes them to kiſſe, meete not with ſuch a touch!

div.stage: [They both draw, and run at him, he ſaues himſelfe behind Pandora.]

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Villaine, and Traytour dye.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: O me! my Maſter.—

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: What doe you meane? ah.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Alas.—Sweet Gentlemen.— Shee layes hold on Neanders arme.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Did all mankinde inhabit in that breaſt,
I'de put the Gods vnto a ſecond trouble
For to create that ſpecies a new.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Woman forbeare.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: I doe not like theſe tumults.
I'le get me home and drinke a cup of Sack.

sp.speaker: Paud.
sp.l: Neander,—
Lucius,—
Ah by that Monſter of my loue, your friendſhip,
Lucius, by theſe eyes of mine, which thou
A thouſand times and more haſt dar'd to liken
Vnto the brighter ſtarre of Venus, which
Is both the Prologue and the Epilogue
Vnto the glorious Sun: By thine owne eyes
Which are two clearer ſtarres, I doe coniure thee
Forbeare to proſecute ſuch a reuenge
Vpon this innocent Boy: for here I ſweare
By all thoſe bleſſed powers, which know our thoughts,
I neuer lou'd him.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Moſt impudent woman,
Did not our eyes behold it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O Neander,
Why doe we ſtand thus coldly here? and not
How out a paſſage through this proſtitute
To trauaile to the iuſt deſtruction
Of her baſe Louer, and my baſer vaſſaile?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Rather let all your fury end in me,
See here my naked breſt imploy your valours:
Why doe you ſtand and gaze one on another?
What is the naked boſome of a Virgin
A ſpectacle of ſuch terrour? if it be,
And that the fight of it hath cool'd your blouds,
Then heare me ſpeake: you Lucius may remember
That ancient ſtock of loue, thoſe many vowes,
Thoſe many teares, thoſe many longings, which
Haue paſt betwixt vs: nor can you iuſtly ſtile it
A fault of mine, that Time is now ſo old
And yet does ſee vs two; but partly yours
Partly my • athers neereneſſe (for I muſt not
Giue it the name it merits, Couetouſneſſe)
Who ſeeing your ſo feruent loue vnto me,
Did ſtriue to thruſt me out with nothing, or
At leaſt with ſuch a portion, as you lik'd not;
Whilſt thus I wauered, betwixt hope, and feare,
It fortun'd, that this Gentleman Neander
Became your Riuall▪ who had not long beene here,
Not long ſollicited, but I (ſhame of women)
Began to loue yee both, and which is more
I lou'd yee with an equall flame, (but ſee
What Pageants Cupid can play!) it chanc'd
(Contrary to all mens expectations)
That by degrees ſuch a ſtrong tye of friendſhip
Did grow betwixt yee, that each of yee refus'd
(For his friends ſake) what then was proferr'd you,
My loue; whilſt I bewayl'd my miſeries
Vnto this Midwife here, my friend, and grieu'd
At this my harder fortune—Good Placenta Shee weepes.
Giue them the reſt.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Then take it in a word.
Suppoſing it the onely way to winne
One of you to her, I counſail'd her to faine
A loue vnto ſome other Gentleman.
Whilſt we were buſie in theſe Conſultations,
As fortune would, your Page Endymion
Came hither (Lucius) to ſeeke his Maſter.
We lay the trayne for him, ſhee courts the Boy,
And he (poore Lad) thinking her ſerious
Was caught immediatly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But is this true?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Would I could call it falſe—But otherwiſe
Then was expected hath it proſpered. Shee weepes.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Placenta, ah Placenta.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Who's that calls me?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Shall I diſcloſe my ſelfe? I am aſham'd. [They put vp their ſwords.]

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: If it be ſo, Pandora, we craue pardon.
And doe reſtore him life; but now (faire ſoule)
If thou do'ſt ayme to reach a life ſo happy
So full of all content, that thou may'ſt fit
Within thy Sphere (like Venus) and looke downe
On all thy Sex, and pitty them; loue this man.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Loue this man. For as for my ſelfe I am
Already furniſh'd with a Miſtris, ſee
My wife here— Sweeteſt wife.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Is this your wife?
I judge her happy who ſo e're ſhee is,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Beleeue him not, this is Boy, a villaine
(Whom I, but that—)

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Lucius forbeare.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Dreſt vp
In womans Cloathes by that ſame dotard Liuely.
Sweeteſt Neander leaue.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: It is a woman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: By all the gods, it is a boy, 'tis falſe.
But for to rob you of all hope of mee
Giue me but care, I am an Eunuch, if
You can endure to haue a frozen ſtatue,
Sleepe by your ſide, whilſt you awake, recount
The tedious minutes of your widdowed nights
And ſigh, and thinke, and thinke, and ſigh againe,
Behold an husband for you, I am he. Shee ſwonnes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: O me! an Eunuch?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Hold the Gentlewoman
Ay me! ſhee ſwonnes, ſweeteſt Pandora, ah.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Ah good Lucius helpe,
Shee's gone — alas good heart. What ſhall I doe?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: But ſee ſhee breathes againe.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Ah hony ſweet
Pandora ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Ah!
Hands off thou out-ſide of a man; and thou
Ʋxorious creature, I doe craue no ayde
From you, forbeare.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: How doe's my ſweeteſt hony?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I am not well Placenta, let vs goe
Into your houſe a while.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pleaſe you faire Lady
To vſe my ſeruice?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How? Your ſeruice ſir?
You can doe nothing, nor doe I expect it.
But if your loue towards me be worthy, lend mee
Your Page, but for an houre.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hee is yours.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Then ſir adiew.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Shall I be vanquiſh'd thus Plac.
In friendſhip? But I will once more to Liuely. Plac.
And ſee what further counſell hee will giue mee, Endym.
Faire wife let's goe—Riſe vp you villaine boy;
Lucius farewell.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What is he gone? ſo ſoone? Exit.
To's Engineer I know, to his contriuer;
But I will follow them ſo faſt, that not
A ſyllable ſhall paſſe without my Knowledge.
Stipes runnes againſt Lucius.How now you Raſcall? where are your eyes I wonder?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: In as a good a headpeece as yours, I warrant you that, for all your fine cloathes, Sands, I thinke my penny as good ſiluer as yours, euery day i'th weeke, I'le tell you but ſo.

A Mayde of eighteene, to play with babes-clouts, well, 'tis no matter, Let that paſſe though, goe to, goe to, 'tis an ill winde that blowes no body good, cry I, ſure
• roſe o'th right ſide to day, I ſhall haue a ſeruant by and by, and a luſty Knaue too, and here's the chincke, the chincke; as I was getting this rod euen now, for my wiſe daughter, comes me Terpanders ſonne, the angry boy, the ſmoaker of Tobacco, the whorſon which could not endure his mother, S • nds I was afraid at firſt to ſee my ſelfe alone with him, he did ſo ſtare with'is rowling eyes, and 'twas no force by'r Lady, for I had fiue good ſhillings in my purſe; But he to put me out of doubt ſalutes me moſt louingly, as thus, Stipes God ſaue you, Saue you Stipes — no, Stipes God ſaue you — Stipes be hang'd — a blockhead, Sd • nds J doubt I ſhould make but a ſcuruie Gentleman, I want the trick ont.— But let that paſſe though, I haue the mony here, and preſently, my man will come, which Anteros will ſend me, whom, if I haue not pay'd me euery morning my forty brace of legges and caps —no more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why ſo, I me fairely accoutred, as becomes a Sheepheards ſeruant — But ſwig for ſee my Maſter. Here muſt I quite diſrobe my ſelfe of all my former manners, garbe, behauiour, and put the plod o'th Cou • try on.—

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: How now? He whiſtles and dances:
What iolly whiſtler haue vve got here trow?
Hi, hi, a dancer too? I, I, by'r Lady
For ought I know, this is the man I ſpoke of,
Or elſe if not, here's one could wiſh hee were.
A ſturdy knaue, a luſty proper knaue.
I like him well, he ha's a backe for burthens.
You Sirrah, you;

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What ſay you, you?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: I ſay whom doe you ſeeke here you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I ſeeke a Sheepheard you.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: I am a Sheepheard.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But I ſeeke a Sheepheard, whoſe name is Stipes.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: I am the man you knaue, you come from Anteros?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yeas.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: To ſerue mee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yeas.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: In good time, how now ſaucy Iacke? how now proud, prodigall knaue? where are your twenty legs vnto your Maſter? Goe to, Goe to, to worke, begin, well ſaid. Anteros makes legs. 1.2.3.4 5 6. So, ſo, enough, I doe forgiue the reſt. Turne you about, vm, vm, a good ſquat fellow, a well quarterd man, By'r Lady, and if hee had but moanes would make a pretty husband for my daughter Merda.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Has he a daughter? and are there women here? o o o— O I am fallen from heauen into a Colepit!

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Why Merda, I ſay, my daughter Merda I ſay, the fooliſh girle's affrayd I know, go to, go to, I will forgiue her. Merda I ſay. But you Sir Squire'oth' dog, what is your name? Hy, which way looke you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My name is Ieoffry.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: I, I, how now? how Ieoffry? a hard name by'r Lady. why when?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O I could creepe into a catskin purſe,
Endure the ſent of a Court-fardingall
For a concealement now.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: Good-hony-ſweet-ſugercandy Father, forgiue mee but this time, and if euer I doe ſo any more, I'le neuer bee ſeene neither byde, or hayre againe.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Ho, ho, oho, ho a great lob, ſtand vp.
I doe forgiue you, but on this condition, that for your penance you ſhall weare this rod, ſtucke at your backe till night.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: With all my heart good Father ſticke it on.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: So: how doeſt thou like my man Chuckin? goe to, looke on him well.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p:
Does hee come a wooing Father? if hee does, I'le
run away, and make him beleeue I'me • oy.— [She offers to run into the houſe. Hee puls her backe with his hooke.]

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Whither now you great baggage? You'l come againe? But ſtay am not I an old foole? an old dotardly foole, that haue not enquir'd what my man can doe yet? Ieoffry.—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Is his name Ieoffry? Father, good father doe, pray you father let him dwell with vs, you know you promis'd me, that you would hire a man, and buy him a Cloake, that he might goe before mee as they doe before Gentlefolkes daughters, when my new gowne was made, I that you did, ſo marry did you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What haue wee now to doe?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
There's claglocks
• now 'ith houſe to make him a cloak Sweete—hony—ſugar—comfit father let him.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: No more. Ieoffry, how now you ſloutch? how doe you ſtand? Come hither, goe to, goe to, did you euer weare a cloake in your life? anſwer mee roundly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No not I, I can't tell how.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Ah beggars brat! how now? but I muſt haue you learne, that you may man your young Miſtris there ſometimes. Come on let mee ſee how finely you can doe the feat, walke before her, follow him daughter. [Hee walkes, Merda ſtayes behind, tying her ſhoe.]

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.p: Here's a ſweet office!

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: You great lobcocke you. [Hee beats him.]
Ile teach you to looke behind you, to ſee whether your charge followes, or no, what? would you bee gadding without your charge?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I, am I arriu'd at this?— whoffer did you ſtrike one?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Doe you prate too? looke you here, marke but mee, I haue ſeene the day, when I could haue ſtinged it before my ſweet heart.—ſhort and thicke cittizen like, you mankin, what? two acres breadth at a ſtride? I, I by'r Lady; Ile cut you ſhort in ſmock-timber, for this minion; is your ſmock ſo wide, with a murren to you? ſhort and thick cittizen like: how now?

div.head: ACT. 4. SCE. 9.
div.stage: Stipes. Anteros. Merda. 2 Ruſticall Seruants. two Mayds. Fidlers.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſt.
sp.p: Hy, ſtrike vp braue boyes, hy, for our towne.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p:
Hy, for your towne ſay you? you are a company of lazy,
lubberly knaues, there's the ſhort and the long on't, ho, ho, boyes, ho, ho boyes? what drabs too? girles too? doxyes too? yee are a company of ſlowbackly Queanes, there's ſauce for your eeles.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruſt.
sp.p: Come Kate, croude on.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O, O, the whole torrent of all woman kind is broke in vpon mee, what ſhall I doe?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Cuds, cuds, theſe are Mr. Livelyes men and mayds, that are come to dance vpon the greene. Pray you Father let mee daunce with them.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: • ou daunce with them? you are a great princockly puplady; there's muſtard for your biefe too, ſince you will needs haue it; 's • nds I haue beene a wit in my dayes, there's ſome reliques left yet, goe to, goe to.

sp.speaker: 1. Mayd.
sp.p: Oh Stipes! I pray you let your daughter daunce with vs a little.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Daunce with you? pray you vpſolue me this queſtion, what holy day is this? Latter Lammas? or St. Ginnyes Even?

sp.speaker: Ruſt. 1.
sp.p: Come on braue Sheepheard, our Maſter ha • given vs leaue to trip it for an hower, or two, I'faith we haue had a wedding at our houſe to day.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: A wedding? a wedding? what wedding? vpſolue mee that queſtion.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſt.
sp.p: Betweene a gentleman and a gentlewoman, but what care wee what they bee.

sp.speaker: 2. Mayd.
sp.p: Come on old Grummelſeedes, what muſt we ſtand thrumming of caps all day, vvaiting on your graue ignorance? by the faith of my body, either let your daughter daunce vvith vs, or I'le make your old bones rattle in your skin, I'le lead you a Coranto I'faith.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: An Amazon, by heauens an Amazon, a Penthiſeleia.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: I, I by'r Lady? are you aviſ'd of that?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Pray you forſooth, good-hony-ſweete-plumpudding father, vvee'l haue but one ſpirt I'faith lavv; Sellengers round in ſippits, or put on thy ſmocke on munday.

sp.speaker: 1 Ruſt.
sp.p: But what flap-mouth'd fellow's that behind the tree there?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now comes my Cue.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Who he? another gates fellow then you take him for, goe to, goe to, it is my man I tell you.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruſt.
sp.p: But can bee daunce?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Oh in print, he trips it like a fayry.

sp.speaker: Ieoff • y.
sp.p: Hy, hy, how now? what? tricks? how now?

sp.speaker: 2. Mayd.
sp.p: How now young man? what ſo modeſt? come on, take mee by th' hand.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Take mee Ieoffry. I'le daunce with our Ieoffry, or elſe I won't dance at all, no I won't, law you now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I can't dance.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p:
Hee's a lying knaue, I ſaw him my ſelfe; to him, to
to him, frolick it nimbly whilſt I come back; becauſe 'tis his firſt day he ſhall haue leaue, my daughter too, for halfe an houre, no more. Go to, go to. Exit Stipes.

div.head: ACT. 4. SCEN. 10.
div.stage: Anteros, Merda, two Rusticall Servants, 2. Ancilla, Fidlers.

sp.speaker: 2 Rust.
sp.p: But ſtrike it out, we burne day-light.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: Ah the Lord! but where's our Ieoffrey?

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Cuds me! I doubt the great clowne's run away.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: Whoo! hee's got up into the tree there.

sp.speaker: 1 Ruſt.
sp.p: Where? where? oh cuds wowkers & ſwowkers, I haue him by the leg: Robin, helpe here Robin.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What a murren ayles you? can't you let one alone?

sp.speaker: 2 Ruſt.
sp.p: Come, come, you muſt needs daunce, we want one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Can't daunce.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.l: Can't you daunce, my little ſhamefac'd one?
Can you kiſſe a pretty wench in a corner?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Let one alone, I can't I tell you, I won't daunce.

sp.speaker: 1 Rust.
sp.p: I but you ſhall ſirrah, in ſpite of your teeth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Piſh, 'won't daunce.

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Come Merda, you muſt entreat him, hee'l daunce with you I know.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Prithee now Ieoffrey doe, prithee now good Ieoffrey doe, wu'd I might ne're ſtir law, if I don't make you a biſning poſſet, with a great lumpe of hony in't, when my father and mother bee gone to bed, if you will.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Piſh I can't daunce.

sp.speaker: 1 Ruſt.
sp.p: Come let the great foole alone, wee'l dance our ſelues.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Prithee now Ieoffrey.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What ſhall I ſay? you'l laugh at one.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Wu'd I was whipt if I doe.

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Beſworne I won't.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: Nor I on my mayden-head.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come on then, ſince there is no remedy. they daunce

sp.speaker: 2 Ruſt.
sp.p: Hi, now every one kiſſe his marrow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I ne're was miſerable 'till now Merda wipes her mouth, and expects

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: Why don't you kiſſe your marrow?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I won't, I can't kiſſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Rust.
sp.p: No can't? wee'l trie that: Robin, hold his tother arme faſt: ſo, ſo, now Merda, now, well ſayd, againe, againe; why ſo then. They all laugh.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: They liue in Paradiſe that thraſh.

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Tihy.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: Tihy, Robin, come hither.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: Thoſe happy Paracelſians are in heauen,
That trade by night i'th mineralls of the citie.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: What doe you meane to fight Merda?

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: Ay-me—I forgot the rod. They laugh.

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Fie, why doe you bluſh ſo Merda? Shee throws it away.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: I don't bluſh, you are a lyer.

sp.speaker: 1 Ruſſ.
sp.p: Fie upon you Merda, a great mayden, and bluſh.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: Aw, but you lye though, I did not bluſh, I won't daunce no more with you.

sp.speaker: 2 Ruſt.
sp.p: O by any meanes doe not forſake us yet, one daunce more; who was it that ſaid ſhee bluſh'd? ſhee did not bluſh, I know ſhe ſcornes to bluſh; come take your Ieoffrey by the hand againe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'm weary, I can't daunce no more.

sp.speaker: 1 Ruſt.
sp.p: Weary? faith I'de ſquiffe it; weary? about with it I ſay. They daunce againe.

div.head: ACT. 4. SCE. 11.
div.stage: Stipes, with two dead lambes vpon his hooke, & caeteri.

sp.speaker: Sti.
sp.p: O lazy varlets! is this a time to daunce? you idle perſons; What will you leaue I ſay? looke heere I pray; doe's this ſame ſpectacle agree with turning on the toe, or capring? go to, go to, fie, fie, ah my ſweet lambes, I dare bee ſworne for you, yee thinke no body hurt at this inſtant. Come hither you my nimble skipper, upſolue me this queſtion, what's your 'pinion muſt be done with theſe?

sp.speaker: 1 Ruſt.
sp.p: Piſh lets away, ſtrike vp, Stipes adiew.

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Farewell Merda.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: And you my ninny peaſe-ſtraw-wiſpe that cannot kiſſe.

sp.speaker: 2 Ruſt.
sp.p: Stipes farewell, hey. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Stipes farewell? but Stipes cannot farewel, if his affaires goe thus quite arſy varſy; you whorſon crab-fac'd lyzard, you left-leg'd rogue, what is there nothing elſe belongs unto this geare, thinke you, but onely to ſtare on them with your two ſawcers of muſtard? s'duds, either take them up quickly, and to worke about them, or Ile — Stipes ſtrikes him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is the ſecond time; this once I'le ſuffer:
But by yon pallace of the Gods I ſweare,
Let him but once more touch me with the top
Of his leaſt finger, and I'le ramme his truncke
Into the center: I haue ſaid it.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Are you muttering? you'l in with them, and diſpatch them; goe you home too, my daughter Merda.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: Vm, vm, vm, you might haue let one daunce a little longer, ſo you might, ſo you might; I am not yet hote in my geares. Exeunt Ant. Merda.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Are you mumbling too? what my whole family turn'd rebels? s'duds—I promiſe you, I promiſe you, 'tis not my beſt courſe I ſee to beat my man thus often; a ſurly knaue by'r Lady, a ſurly knaue, a ſtrong knaue too, I doe not like his lookes, he has a vineger countenance: but peace and catch a mouſe, cry I.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: But ſee, I will enquire; honeſt man, a word.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Honeſt man in your face, whoſoe're owes you; 'sduds, haue I nothing to doe, but to prittle, prattle, with euery one I meet, thinke you? Exit.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: What an unheard of rudeneſſe haue we here?
Are theſe the manners of the countrey? well.
This is the place, as I am told, wherein
That Lucius liues, who not long ſince prevayl'd
With his faire flattering ſpeeches, for to haue
My ſonne Endymion to be his Page.
But oh yee awfull powers!
I had no father in mee ſhould I ſuffer
Mine onely ſonne to lead a ſervile life
With one that is mine enemy, nay more,
The ruine and ſubverſion of my family.
O daughter Iſabella!
Whilſt thy falſe Lover melts within the armes
Of his new purchac'd Miſtris, thou (poore girle)
Embraceſt ſcorne and povertie, or elſe
(Which I doe rather wiſh were true) cold death.
But I doe heare,
Since my arrivall, of ſome Country people,
That they haue ſeene, ſome fortnight ſince or more,
A pretty boy, lingring about this village
Much about her ſtature, and complexion,
Which did enquire for a Gentleman
That was without a Page; this may be ſhee,
Who for the loue of Lucius, has put on
Some ſtrange diſguiſe. Whom cannot loue transforme?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he.
Whilſt the poore flye does ſport her ſelfe too long
About the amorous flame, ſhe burnes her wings.
Her counterfeiting of a Loue, is now
Turn'd into earneſt. Endymion's now the man
She ſweares ſhe loues; as for the other two
She has forgot their very names already.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Does not this woman name my ſonne?
Let me ſee, is not this Endymion? it is hee, Enter Pand. Endymion.
And with him a fayre gentlewoman. Ha?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: But tell me deareſt, did thy Maſter Lucius.
Once loue thy ſiſter Iſabella ſo,
Whom now he has forſaken?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Behold
That treachery repayd him.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: See, they kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: But what old Gentleman is this?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'le ſhew my ſelfe.
All health to this faire loving couple.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Why do'ſt thou flie me?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: 'Tis my father,— father
God ſaue you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Deareſt ſonne, my beſt of bleſſings.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: How haue you done ſir, ſince I ſaw you laſt?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: As well as one can doe that has departed
With's onely daughter.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Why, is my ſiſter dead?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: I know not that. But I am ſure her credit,
The candor of her name is periſhed.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Good ſir, as how? Inſtruct me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ah Endymion,
Since that moſt treacherous Lucius left the Citie
I haue not ſeene her, onely I heare of her,
But little to my comfort.—But no more,
I haue forgot her, and her folly both.
Prepare thy ſelfe (my ſonne) immediatly,
To leaue this place and ſervice; for thy fortunes
(How e're they were before, ſlender and poore)
Muſt not now ſee thee hold a trencher for
A better man then Lucius. Thy old vncle
As he liv'd well, in a ſeaſonable age
Is gone into the graue, and by his will
Hath given to thee eight thouſand pound, and three
Vnto thy ſiſter, (though unworthy) what
Elſe he was worth in lands and goods, is mine.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Pandora, kiſse mee girle, kiſse mee I ſay,
I haue deſerued it, 'twas my invention,
My plot this (girle) th'art happy wench, th'art happy.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Is this your father ſweet?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: It is faire Miſtris.
Sir, I congratulate our fortunes with you;
But if you doe deſire to haue my joyes
Full and o'reflow their banks, grant me your leaue
To marry this faire Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Alas,
This is not in my power Endymion:
But if thou canſt procure her friends conſent—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir feare not that, I will entreat my father.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: As for a portion, 'tis not thought upon
My ſon, if you be pleas'd.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Sir, I am pleas'd,
Shee is to me moſt deare.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Placenta, runne,
See if my father be within,—I know Ex. Pla.
(Moſt worthy ſir) that I ſhall win him to it.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: But canſt thou tell no newes of Iſabella,
Sweet ſon?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: No, none at all ſir.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ah poore heart!
But 'tis no matter, I'le forget her quite. Redit in ſcenam Plac.
Where is thy Mr Lucius?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Your father's walk'd abroad with Mis. Vrſely
Your ſiſter, but whither, there's none can tell me.
As yet the plot concerning Conſtantina to herſelfe.
Is not deſcri'd.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Moſt reverend ſir, wilt pleaſe you
To walke into the paſtures, peradventure
There we ſhall meet my father.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: But I had rather
That I could compaſſe that ſame villaine Lucius,
That he might heare what he deſerues. Liuely runns in, Nean. following with his ſword drawne.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Villaine.

sp.speaker: Live.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Ah me! Neander with his naked ſword!
Ple runne in heere.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Ah!

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Let's away good father, Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: O that thou hadſt
As many liues as haires, that I might be
An age in killing thee, that I might ſcore up
Each paſſing minute with a life: — But ſpeake,
How durſt thou thus abuſe me?

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: I did not know
Shee was a woman.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: No, didſt thou not know it?
But thou ſhalt know thy ſelfe to be a man,
One that can dye.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: —O—O—

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: How poore is this reuenge? haſt thou any children,
Or kinsfolkes (ſpeak) that I may kill them too?
Ha? wilt thou not anſwer? how durſt thou offer this?

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Becauſe I loued your friend Lucius
Better then you.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Better then I? that word
Does merit death though thou hadſt beene preſeru'd
White from thy cradle to this houre.—
Doeſt thou loue Lucius? ha?

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Liue; no, no thou muſt not;
Thou might'ſt haue kil'd my father, broke the vrne
Wherein my mothers aſhes ſleepe, farre cheaper.
But for his ſake, thus much I'le grant thee, chuſe
The manner of thy death—ſhall I take off thy head?
Or hadſt thou rather dye vpon the poynt?
Thinke quickly, nay be inſtant.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Worthy Sir:
Let mee entreate ſome little ſpace to pauſe
I haue not yet determin'd.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Well thou haſt it. But ſee that it bee ſpeedy.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Moſt perfidious. Contemner of all goodneſſe.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Excellent.
Nay forward, on, wee know you haue a tongue.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Ha? is this Lucius?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Where is my Iſabella,
Whom thou haſt loaden with diſgrace? reſtore mee
Her honour (villaine) her good name.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: I muſt
Deferre my iuſt reuenge I ſee a little.
He muſt not know that I am angry, not
How I am gulld.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Thou baſe unworthy man.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Would you could raiſe your voyce a little ſir,
You are not heard.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Thou ſtaine of all mankind.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Thou oweſt thy life unto my Lucius.
I am not now at leaſure for to kill thee.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Nor I for to be kild for a trick I know. Ex. Liuely.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Are you drawne drie ſo quickly, Mr Lickthumbe?
Haue you no more good names in pickle for me?
Nay come ifaith, let's haue an other bout.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: But is he gone? he muſt not ſo eſcape me. Ex. Nean.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Where is my daughter? where is my daughter, raſcall?
Ah Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: So: but Sir reſolue mee,
Haue yee no Empericks? no Phyſitians
I'th Citty, that you thus doe ſend your mad men
Into the country to be cur'd? but Sir
I'le leaue you.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: But I will not ſo leaue you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You will not?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: No, I'le be a torment to thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You will? but yet take heed that your ill language
Procures not me to turne Phyſician.
This ſword of mine opens a veine but harſhly,
Doe you heare.

lg.l: Haue you a deſire to ſee
The glorious heavens Epitome?
Or an abſtract of the Spring?
Adonis garden? or a thing
Fuller of wonder, Natures ſhop diſplay'd,
Hung with the choyceſt pieces ſhe has made?
Here behold it open layd.
Or elſe would you bleſſe your eyes
With a type of paradiſe?
Or behold how Poets faine
Ioue to ſit amidst his traine?
Or ſee (what made Acteon rue)
Diana 'mongst her Virgin crue?
Lift up your eyes and view.

div.head: ACT. 5. SCEN. 1.
div.l: Why ſo then, now we are all alone. We? you great neare,
What haue you pig's in your belly? by'r Lady, If I wiſt
I had, I would not vnkennell this ſecret yet, well if there
Were hog's in my belly too, I ſee that it will out;
This mouth of mine was not cut out for ſecret's—
O wicked ſeruant! lewd daughter!
O Merda, Merda, thou haſt loſt thy ſelfe
div.p: For euer, thou haſt defiled my houſe, my good name, my family. As I even now came from my ſheepe, I found my daughter, at her nooning forſooth, faſt a ſlepe vpon her bed, and there was ſhee (as ſhee vſes often) campring to her ſelfe alone in her ſleepe, 'ſcourſing to her ſelfe, but what was her 'ſcourſe thinke you?
