Not about her huſwifery; not how many hens were with egge, but fie vpon you Ieoffry are you not aſhamed? O! Ah! fie vpon you Ieoffry are you not aſhamed to touch one by the skinne? Ile tell my father (nere moue) if you will not bee quiet. I, I by'r Lady, worſe then this, worſe ſtuffe then this, what ſhall I ſay? without all doubt this left legd-raſcall has dub'd mee Gran-father without Matrimony. But peace and catch a mouſe cry I, ſome wiſer then ſome, old birds will not be catch'd wi • h ſhaffe. I haue a trick in ſtore if it will take, to be reueng'd ſufficiently—no more. Ieoffry, Why Ieoffry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What gaping knaue is that?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: How now Ieoffry? know you not mee Ieoffry? know you not mee? But let that paſſe though—I'le bee with you anon i'faith for all this geere. Come hither Left-legs, come hither. Peace and catch a mouſe cry I. Did you euer when you were at your old Maſters, learne to ſet a trap, Ieoffry?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes a mouſe trap.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p:
O ſirrah, ſirrah; but wee muſt haue to doe with other gates kind of cattell, I meane a fox trap Left-legs, come hither, come hither, looke you here, and learne, for this ſame night muſt
I ſend you into the Paſtures to inuite my fine Reynold to morrow to breake-faſt, goe too, goe too, hee is ſomething too familiar with my Lambs, marke you that left-legs? A little nigher I pray you. Helpe me to twiſt this Corde — Well ſaid, be a faithful ſeruant Ieoffry. You know I haue a daughter Ieofry. Peace and catch a Mouſe Ieoffry. You great dunder noſe — Souds— You' • e lay both hands to work—A bots on you; you hang on my back to ſee you. Your tother hand in, and draw behind thus, thus looke you here. [He gets his hands into the cordes, and on a ſuddaine tyes him too a tree.] Ha, ha, he, foh. How ranke he ſmells? but 'tis no matter, I begin to grow old, and 'tis good (they ſay) Againſt the Palſey. Ha, ha, he, he, ho. You villaine, Hee loues
Mutton well, that dips his bread in'th wooll.
No leſſe then your Maſters daughter Left-legs?
Come on in troth, vpſolue me this queſtion is ſhe not tender? is ſhe not delicate? a pretty morſell? does ſhee not relliſh well? a pretty morſell? but I'le teach you ſirrah to play the Maſon, and lay your chips o'th rock where you're deſired Left-legs, where you're deſired. But I am ſomething feeble through my age,
And cannot longer hold out 'ſcourſe with you,
Without my ſtaff, without my ſupporter, ſir,
I pray you doe not ſtirre till my returne,
But let me finde yeu here, I haue ſome buſineſſe,
Goe to, goe to, I haue ſome buſineſſe with you. Exit Stipes.

div.head: ACT. 5. SCE. 3.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay 'tis no matter I deſerue it all,
Troth I doe hope that he will baſt me ſoundly.
Beſhrow his fingers if he does not, ſoundly.
I muſt be in my tricks, forſooth, my tricks:
Haue my devices, and my turnes, my changes. Enter Loueall.
But torment of all torments! here comes Loueall.
Why this is worſe then fiue and twenty beatings;
O that ſome greedy vndertaker of liues
Would giue me but a double Stiuer now
For mine, that I might cozen him. As ſure
As Death, or Iuſtice Hookes deuouring pawes,
I ſhall be ieer'd to death, immediatly.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: It is a ſtrange darke melancholly this
That thus torments my Siſter, I haue beene
An houre with her, and in all that time
Cannot perſwade her troubled ſoule to forme
The leaſt ayre ſhee breathes, into articulate language.
But ſtay what haue wee here?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now it begin's.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: A man tyed to a tree?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would your tongue
Was tyed as faſt; then there was hope I might
Eſcape with life.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What are you fellow, ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You may goe looke, goe meddle with your owne.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: So angry 'pray thee? how came thy hands in morgage?
Shall I redeeme them?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Redeeme your owne land's I pray you,
Let me alone or elſe I'le ſpurne yo u— yet
Hee knowes mee not.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Sure I haue ſeene that face.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O, O, O —

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Is 't hee or not, ha? Anteros.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more.
Death not a word.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But heauen and earth man! how
Comes this to paſſe? What has begot this change?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wilt thou vnty me? I will tell thee all.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But pray thee Anteros.—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But pray thee Iack
Thou wilt vndoe me quite by thy delayes,
Wilt thou vndoe me?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: 'Tis not a friendly part.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pox o' that ieaſt, as common as a woman,
Or her Synonomy; wilt thou vnty mee? He vntyes him.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou art my Patron Loueall, So.
But ſtay a while, I muſt deſire your ayde
A little further.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What has hee now in hand?

div.stage: [He pulls off his Shepheards robes which were aboue his owne, pluckes Garters, Pumps, Roſes, a Band out of his Pocket.]

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Can you become a peaceable man?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: How now?
A Snake, a Snake; hee's young againe, ha, ha, he.
What? Pinkes and Roſes too? Why ſo, hee pluckes
Iune out of 's pocket.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Can you be quiet yet?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: And Garters too?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That ſlipper▪ tongue of yours
I doubt will ſpoyle all.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What? and a band? ſo, ſo;
The vayle of Tempe's not ſo freſh, the picture,
The very picture of the Spring, when th' earth
Layes by her freeze-coate, and turnes Forreſter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thus far it proſpers, once more your help ſweet Iack,
Nay come, and take me that ſame rope againe,
And binde me as I was before, directly
In the ſame garbe you found me — Doe not ſtand
Gazing, but do 't.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Thou art not mad I hope?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If I be mad, I will not trouble you
For counſaile, nor for Phyſick; nay wilt thou come?
But hold a little, I muſt firſt borrow of you
Your Hat, and Sword. [Hee lends him his hat and ſword.]

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Which way this plot will looke
I know not— there— come let me ſee your hand's
Since you wil needs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why now thou'rt right, thou'rt right,

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What will you haue me doe beſides? come on,
Your legges too if you will.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more, St. harke.
The Sheepheards doore. Trouble vs not good Loueall.
Onely ſtand cloſe and heare.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What ſhould this meane?

div.head: ACT. 5. SCEN. 4.
div.stage: Stipes with a cudgell in his hand. Anteros. Loueall.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Fie Ieoffry, are yeu not aſham'd, to touch one by the skinne? My daughter denies all this moſt ſtifly but I will Ferret-claw my Lobcock i'faith. So, now I am arm'd. Goe to, goe to, come you knaue, where are you?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Ha? ha? ha? How now by'r Lady? How now? I, I by'r Lady? what's this? What's this? gaudy? gaudy? Fine cloathes? fine cloathes? Ha? has no body ſtole my eyes? let me be ſure of that in the firſt place. Am I Stipes or not? ha? ha? ha? Is this our Ieoffry or not?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Stipes, Stipes I ſay.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: This is another voyce an other face
Without all queſtion this is Fayrie Ground;
My man is chang'd.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: St. Stip. hi, hi, hi. A ſweard too? a ſweard too? a whiniard too?

sp.speaker: Stip
sp.p: Well I will venture to ſpeake what ere come on 't, but ſtay, I'le firſt ſay o're the charme my Mother learnt me.
sp.l: Beeſt thou deuill gentle, or beeſt thou deuill curſt,
In the name of Saint Swithin doe thy worſt.
sp.p: There's ſauce for your Ecles what e're you are. Now ſee if I cannot ſhape you an anſwere.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come nearer to mee.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Are you auis'd of that? older and wiſer, Soft fire makes ſweet Mault, No haſt to hang true men; come nearer quoth you? I am neare enough already for the good you'le doe me I doubt, Come nearer ſay you? No good M. Deuill I am very wel I thank you, goe to, come nearer when you haue a Sweard, a Twybill?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My hands are bound man.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: What wil becom of this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: St'. Stip. If your feet were bound too, I'le not truſt you As long as you haue a Sweard by your ſide, a Whiniard.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Do but heare me. Had not you a man to day call'd Ieoffry?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Yes marry had I; what ſay you to that now? Nay I'le keepe my ſelfe out of your clouches I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But what's become of that ſame Ieoffry?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Become? become? 'ſpoſe I ſpurd you an anſwere, and ſaid I know not, what can you make of that now? make mee a horſenaile of that.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Doe you deſire to know?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Yes marry doe I. Crack mee that nut now if you be a Gentleman Deuill.—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am that Ieoffry, but no ſeruant now
Of your's, but mine owne man: and am become
Since your departure, noble, rich, valiant,
Am form'd a new out of the Mint, —behold me.
And this great miracle Obron the Fayry King
Has wrought vpon me.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Oberum? Oberum? you tell me ſtrange things.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But ſhal I tel thee ſtranger things thē theſe?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: 'Spoſe you did.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And ſuch as ſhall be for thy benefit?—

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Would you would elſe. Nay ſtare on with your gogles till Barly comes to ſix pence a buſhell. You know your wages, ſome wiſer then ſome, cry I: I'le keepe farre enough off you: I'le tell you but ſo. Goe to, goe to, I am a crafty colt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You know I vvas your ſeruant to day.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Well put the caſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Poore, ill apparelled.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Put the caſe the ſecond time.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But now you ſee how ſtrangely altered.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Well put the caſe againe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: VVhat vvill you ſay now to the man that ſhall
Pet you into the ſame condition?
Recouer you from rag's and Ruſſet, and
Dye you in ſcarlet: lick that rude lump your body
Into the ſhape, and garbe o'th court? or (once)
Make you a gentleman as I am now?
Would you not thanke him Stipes? ha? would you not thanke him?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Thanke him Mr. Ieoffry? I, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Set him at liberty then that will performe it. Quickly vnlooſe me? [Hee vntyes him.]

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: I, I by'r Lady? will you ſo Mr. Ieoffry? will you ſo? goe to, goe to, a gentleman? ſayd you mee ſo? I con you thanke Mr. Ieoffry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So, now will I vnfold the myſterie.
But firſt you here ſhall promiſe mee that you
Will take noe prentiſes to learne your trade,
When I haue taught you the art; you will impoueriſh
The herald's office, and foreſtall his market.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: No truely Mr. Ieoffry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am ſatisfied;
Seeſt thou that tree? 'twas made for thy aduancement.
Giue mee thy hands that I may tye them quickly.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Are you avis'd o' that?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What doe you meane?
You'le bee preuented by another—death!
Yonder comes one will be before you—quickly
There's ſuch a vertue (man) in this ſame tree,
That who-ſoere is bound vnto it, ſhall
Bee turn'd immediately to a gentleman.
Nay come.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: but is this true?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: beleeue your eyes.
Heart of my father, man! youle bee preuented.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: A gentleman? ſayd you me ſo? goe to, goe to, [He tyes Stipes to the tree.] Good Maſter Ieoffry quickly—ſo but ſtay. When I'me a gentleman may I not vſe, my old trade of ſheepherd ſtill? I would not leaue it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O, and incloſe; 'tis all in faſhion.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: I, I, by'r Lady? thats well, but ſtay againe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay you are like to ſtay now, I haue you faſt enough

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: 'Sduds, if thou be'ſt a good coniurer make me a knight to. I haue a peſtilent itch after a knighthood.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You muſt take gentleman firſt 'ith way.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: Let mee skip gentleman good Mr. Ieoffry, 'duds
I know knights in this countrey that neuer were
Gentlemen—but vpſolue me this queſtion? can you make
My daughter Merda a gentleman too?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A gentlewoman
Stipes I can.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: I, I, ſo I meant it— Merda, Merda,
A bots on you, Merda, are you dreaming againe?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O for ſome nimble pated fellow now
To make an Ob'ron of.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Ile furniſh thee.
There is a notable witty bedlam begging
At our back gate iuſt now. I'le fetch him to thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If thou do'ſt loue mee, doe.— Exit Loueall.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Why Merda, you'l come when your nowne father cals?

div.head: ACT. 5. SCE. 5.
div.stage: Merda. Stipes. Anteros. Loveall. A Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Merda.
sp.p: What doe you ſay Father forſooth?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: That 's a good girle. Nay ſhee 's towardly enough, ſhee' • quickly learne. Why doe you ſtare ſo on Mr. Ieoffry?

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: What man is this Father?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Come you'r a foole, let that man alone. Wee ſhall bee gentlefolkes ourſelues my chucken, giue him your hands to ty I ſay, be obedient.
sp.l: Thou preſently ſhalt ſee thine owne ſweet father,
As fine as hee, and thou my litle Sweet-lipp's
Shalt be a gentlewoman too, goe to, good Ieoffry tye her hands.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How Ieoffry?

sp.speaker: Sti.
sp.p: Good Mr. Ieoffry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That's another thing.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Father forſooth ſhall I haue as fine cloth's on as Miſtris V • ſly forſooth?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: O! ſhe's halfe turn'd already: forſooth and a curtſey at euery word; Mrs. Vrſely? thou ſhalt put Mrs. Ʋrſly into a pint pot.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: O the Lord! pray you forſooth Sir who ſoe're you are doe mee quickly forſooth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But here 's not rope enough.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Take off your garter quickly you Maukin you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Here forſooth. And father, muſt I take place of my mother when I'm a Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Marry ſhalt thou goldy locks, and be a Lady, and contemne her.
Call her the good old country woman too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stipes, but one word more and then I'le leaue you
Vnto your new creation—haue you nothing
Within your houſe to couer you? the crowes
Perhaps may bee too impudent and ſaucy
With you, and now you can not helpe your ſelfe you know.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: I, I by'r Lady? 'twas well thought vpon,
Good Mr. Ieoffry ſtep into my houſe, He goes out and returnes preſently with a long gray cloak.
You there ſhall finde my cloake, vſe that.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis of a ſwooping cut, but new be ſure
You doe not ſpeake a word what noiſe ſo ere
You chance to heare, perhaps the fairy King
Will take ſome pawſe, ſtudy a while, conſult
With his Queene Mab about you how to poliſh
And frame you of a purer ſhape then ordinary.
Doe you marke that? St, not a word good Stipes.

sp.speaker: Stip
sp.p: Ah ſweet Mr. Ieoffry. [Enter Loueall with a Bedlam.]

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Peace and catch a mouſe cry I.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Come on braue Tom, come on braue Tom, Remember your inſtructions Tom.

sp.speaker: Bedl.
sp.p: Let braue Tom alone. Let braue Tome alone.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A moſt authentick rogue, how he does ſtretch it? paratragoediate?

sp.speaker: Bedlam ſings.
sp.l: Newly from a poach'd Trade, and
A broyl a Viper, King of Fayry land
I Ob'ron doe ariſe, to ſee
What mortall Fortune here hath tyed vnto my ſacred Tree.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: O Mr. Ieoffry, is that Ob'rum? Pray you let me ſee him. [Ant lifts vp the cloake and Stipes ſees him.] Is this Obrum? 'sduds, hee is but poorely parrelled himſelfe me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: St. Stip. Peace and catch a mouſe cry I, but once more good Mr. Ieoffry. Let me haue but Ant lifts vp the cloake againe. one ſight more of him. Mr. Ieoffry does hee vſe to giue away his cloathes when hee makes gentlefolkes? 'sduds I doubt he has none left for me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Peace and catch a mouſe cry I.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Good father let mee ſee Obrum too • ah, hee has a horne like a Tom of Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Peace, I wu'd not for the beſt cow in my yard that he ſhould heare thee.

sp.speaker: Bedlam ſings.
sp.l: Beeſt thou ruder then was e're
The halfe excrement of a Beare,
Or rougher then the Northerne winde
Cam'ſt thou of a Satyres kind.
Be whatſoeuer thou can'ſt be
So thou ſhalt remaine for mee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Did you heare that Stipes?

sp.speaker: Stip:
sp.p:
I, good Maſter
Ieoffry, ſtand farther you great baggage and make roome for your rathers' proaching greatneſſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But ſee my father,

sp.speaker: Loveall.
sp.p: 'Pray thee conuey away the Bedlam any whether, carry him into your houſe againe and ſhoote him out at the back dore.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Anteros, I'le leaue you to your buſines. I'le in and fetch an other hat. Come bra • e Tom. 'Bed, Let braue Tom alone. [Ex. Lou. & Bedlam.]

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The Iuſtice too, 'tis ſo. Now am I hunted for about a wedding.

div.head: ACT. 5. SCE. 6.
div.stage: Iuſtice Hooke, Terpander, Anteros Mrs. Vrſly.

sp.speaker: Hooke.
sp.l: Terpander, you haue heard how much this match
May both concerne you and your Sonne, your fortunes:
The greater part of your inheritance
You know is mortgag'd to mee, nay (Ile tell you)
If I would vſe that rigour of the law
'Tis forfeited and paſt recouery;
Thinke therefore quickly, if you would be free
From all thoſe cares and troubles which afflict
Such as do liue in debt, compell your Son
To marry this my daughter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am a witch,
A witch, a witch a rancke, ſtarke ſtinking witch.

sp.speaker: Hooke.
sp.l: It is an ample dowrie I confeſſe,
And litle 'tis agreeing to my nature
To buy a husband at ſo deare a rate,
But I haue ſomething that ſounds father in mee;
And muſt not looſe a daughter, if there bee
A remedy in nature. True it is,
That (by what angry Deity I know not)
Shee has ſo fixt her loue vpon your Son,
That I doe thinke naught but a quick fruition
Can reſcue her from a death.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Good Iuſtice Hooke,
I doe confeſſe your offer's fayre, and would
Accept it willingly, but that—

sp.speaker: Hooke.
sp.l: But what?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I feare my Son will not agree vnto 't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir had you ta'ne an oath vpon the ſame
I would haue borne your ſin, had you beene periur'd.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You know he hates all women.

sp.speaker: Hooke.
sp.l: very good.
Is he not your's, and vnder your command?
Wee fathers make our children refractory,
By being too indulgent over them;
Beſides, I am perſwaded that his vertues
Will not permit him for to contradict
Th' authority of a father.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O ye Gods!
Can ye permit this Villaine to profane
The ſacred name of Vertue thus, who himſelfe
Is nothing elſs but a meere heape of vices?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I ever yet found him obedient,
Nor doe I doubt to win him now: how ever,
I am reſolv'd if he in this ſhall croſſe me,
I'le diſinherit him immediatly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I? is it come to that already? well
Prepare thy ſelfe now Anteros for th' encounter.

sp.speaker: Hooke,
sp.l: But ſee your ſonne. Tis your beſt courſe at firſt
T' accoſt him gently.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: How now my ſon? how fare you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am not well ſir.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: How not well? your colour
Does not proclaime you very ſicke, but ſay.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ther's ſomething in my eyes that troubles me.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A mote, a woman.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: After the old faſhiō ſtill?
Come on my ſon, I haue bin ſeeking of you,
And peradventure you may gueſſe the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would I could not.

sp.speaker: Hooke.
sp.l: Hold up your head my daughter
And ſummon your beſt lookes into your face.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: As I did walke even now into my paſture,
I did begin to thinke.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That I was old,
That muſt be next.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: That now I'me ſtrucke in yeares.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good, ſtrucke in yeares;
And could he not as frugally have diſpatcht it
In that one word of old?

sp.speaker: Ter:
sp.l: And —

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: That it will be a comfortable ſight
To ſee you marryed before I dye.

sp.speaker: Ter:
sp.l: That it will be a comfortable ſight
To ſee you marryed before my death.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: I told you ſo, it is the common roade
Which they all uſe when they would pin a wife
Vpon the ſon. I wonder all this while
The ſtaffe of's age, propp of his family
Did not come in.

sp.speaker: Ter:
sp.l: Whileſt I was thinking thus,
Old juſtice Hooke, a Gentleman of rancke,
And of a family not to be deſpiſ'd,
Came to me with his daughter, and deſir'd
Our friendſhip and affinitie; and to be briefe,
We haue concluded 'twixt yee two a marriage,
Which muſt be preſent; as for the portion,
H'as promis'd in the wedding fire to ſacrifice
The Bonds wherein our Lands ſtand forfeited.
A thing beyond my hopes, or your deſerts.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A pox upon that thumbe under the girdle,
There 's miſchiefe ever toward's: I never knew
One of that garbe that prov'd an honeſt man.
'Tis the graue cheating poſture of the citie.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: What's that you mutter to your ſelfe? come ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am contented ſir.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Well ſaid my ſon.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But upon this condition, that it ſhall
Be lawfull too for me to ſacrifice
Vnto the aforeſaid fire a certaine trifle
Of mine.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Whats that?
My wife, & your faire daughter.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Out on you traytor.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, by yea and nay
It cannot be afforded cheaper.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Wretch
And profane perſon.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Sai'ſt thou ſo thou villaine?
Haſt thou no more regard into thy father,
Nor to his ſhipwrackt fortun, that thou thus▪
Doeſt ſtudie his undoing plot his 〈◊〉 ?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But father, if I marry her to day,
When muſt the wooing be? to morrow ſir?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not need to wooe her Anteros,
Shee is thine owne already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is ſhee ſo?
Would you was hang'd ſir for the nowes.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Piſh, dome,
I will not ſpend an article of ayre
Vpon him more — good Mr Hooke lets goe,
The following houre ſhall ſee him no ſon of mine.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: O, mildly ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is determined
By all the ſtarres, they haue conſulted, plotted
To make me miſerable.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Come Terpander,
You are too harſh with him, I know your ſonne
Does more eſteeme of Vertue and Religion —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good Maſter Sucriledge, a word in private:
(A little farther, yet a little farther)
How came you by that ſtrange exotick word
You us'd but now? had you'r on intereſt?

Or was it lent you gra •
of a friend?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: What word good Anteros?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: For I am ſure yet thou never hadſt,
Nor ever wilt haue any of thine owne.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: O profane perſon!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: This once I ſpeake it.
Wilt haue his daughter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What ſhall I anſwer him?
I ſhall be diſ-inherited that's certaine.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: He melts, Mr Hooke, hee melts, I feele him comming.
Hee is our owne.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But why ſo ſuddenly?
Good ſir, at leaſt giue me ſome time to think.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Never hope it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But why ſir to day?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Becauſe it pleaſeth him it moſt concernes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Doe but deferr it till to morrow ſir,
(Could I obtaine but this requeſt, I was happy, aſide.
I'de keepe to morrow in another world)

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Vntill to morrow? not for an houre: I know
Your diſpoſition ſonne too well for that.
I haue you now, but where you'l be next day,
Hee 's wiſer then your father that does know.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But father, I beſeech you heare.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: But ſon
I will not heare, I tell you. Maſter Hooke,
You here doe giue your daughter?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Willingly.
Anteros, receiue thy loving wife.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: How now?
You will not urge me?—goe too, doe not doe it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O that mine armes are now at libertie!
O Stipes, happieſt man aliue, thou haſt
No hands to make a contract, —is there never
A Mouſe-hole hereabouts to creepe into?
But ſtay a while, my paper portion.
The writings.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Take them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You'r an honeſt man.
sp.stage: [He giues them him, & Ant. teares thē in pieces.]
sp.l: Tis right.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Now take your wife.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I wiſh you a Barber ſir.
Is that faire Edifice yours?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: It is my ſonne.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Gooder and gooder ſtill; my ſon? then take
My counſell ſir, go to your houſe and purge,
You will be mad elſe preſently; prevent
The current of the humour, for I ſee
(With that poore little reading which I haue
I'th volume of man) by your diſtempered looks,
That ſome ſtrange deepe, and conquering Melancholy
E're long will ſeize you: why doe you follow me
Thus with your braided ware? nay never frowne,
Good Mr Iuſtice, let's haue no Warrants made,
Nor Mittimuſſes with your diſtorted lookes;
Wee haue a forehead too, and can looke grim,
And make as ugly and prodigious faces,
As the moſt ignorant Iustice of you all.
But ſhall I tell you (ſweet Mr Velvet-hoſe)
What I will doe, becauſe you were ſo kind,
For to deliuer in the Bonds for nothing?
Nay ſir, I muſt tranſplant theſe thumbes, before
I can reſolue you: ſo.—Thou 'rt a damn'd raſcall,
And I will cut that throat of thine (doe you marke?)
And when I'ue done, will fillip that morſell, woman,
On an embaſſage to my Hawkes, no more;
By heauens I'le do 't.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Oh Traytor, Miſcreant,
Daughter take heed; Terpander, O Terpander,
He threatens me to cut my throat.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, you muſt pardon him, the man is mad.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: He ſweares he will make hawkesmeat of my daughter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: On my virginitie ſir, he does me wrong;
I did not charge a ſyllable upon him,
But fell as coolely from me as a dew.
Vpon a drooping field; each word I vented
VVas ſteep'd in an hony-combe. I did but bid him
In a plaine, civill dialect to provide
An other husband for his daughter: for
I doubted that I ſhould not be at leaſure
This brace or two of yeeres to marry her.
And I may tell you ſir, indeed I cannot.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: O, O, am undone, cheated and gull'd, undone,
Villaine I'le bind thee to thy good behaviour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would you could ſir, I would thank you for't:
But fie M. Hooke, a head of that ſilver dye,
A beard of ſuch an honourable length,
For to bee gull'd? and ſo egregiouſly?
By a young man with ne're a haire o'ns face?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Come ſonne, I doe not like theſe courſes, nor
Doe they become a Gentleman, I'le not haue
That contumely dwell on our family,
That we ſhould uſe ſuch indirect proceedings
For to reedifie our tottering fortunes.
By all the Magicke in the name of Father
I doe conjure thee; by this aged head,
And theſe gray hayres, by thy dead Mothers Vrne,
By all her cares and feares, by what is deareſt
Vnto thy ſoule, I charge thee, take his daughter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Without all queſtion I am the firſt, the firſt
That ever pietie has made miſerable.
Well Maſter Hooke, you ſee what may be done,
VVhat angry ſpirits a man may lay, while he
Does ſtand ſecure within the circle of father.
Your daughter I will haue; onely know this,
There is another thing which belongs to her,
Which I muſt haue too, that's the Parſonage;
'Twas ever yet allotted for her portion,
And I expect my right.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: How? woe is me,
I am undone.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Before I ſtretch forth a paw
Towards her, i'le haue it.

sp.speaker: Vrſ.
sp.l: Father, good father let him,
He will go back from's word els.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Well, he ſhall haue it.
Hold: by the vertue of this writing, it
Is lawfull for you (after old Liuelyes death)
For to preſent the firſt Fy, fy, fy, fy.
I had this drawne (alas) for another end.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My law does tell mee it will doe. Come on,
Since there's no remedy, let's even to't.
Yes hangman, I forgiue thee heartily,
'Tis but thy office.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Come Terpander, we
VVill keepe the wedding, at my houſe, but heare you?
The coſt and charges ſhall be yours.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Agreed,
Moſt willingly. Follow me ſonne and daughter.

div.stage: [She fits downe, & puls ſtones out of her pocket]

sp.speaker: Vrſe.
sp.l: Come husband Anteros, will you play at chackstones
VVith me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Follow, follow, follow, follow,
I will bee there immediatly: nay goe.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: So, I haue made a fine dayes worke of this:—
Well, there's no remedy, it muſt be ſo.
But I muſt take my leaue in forme: Farewell
Yee chimney gods, protectours of our family;

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: A bott's vpon you, that ſame tongue
Of yours muſt needs be wagging.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Indeed Father
I did not ſpeake a word, no that I did not.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: Wee muſt begin againe now for your tatling,
Did not the Gentleman command vs ſilence?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stipes adiew, I am exceeding ſorry
I cannot ſtay to ſee you a Gentleman.
Spruce M. Noddle, euen adiew to you.
Good M. Mungrell, kinde Sir Hammerſhin.
Sweet M. William, I am Melancholly
To part with you as I am a liuing ſaule.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Why whether in ſuch haſt?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To baniſhment.
My name is written in the oyſter ſhell;
I am too happy in a wife Iack Loueall,
My fellow Cittizens doe enuie me.
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: In troth I thanke you hartily,
I hope you'l firſt deliuer back againe
My Sword and Hatt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By my beſt wiſhes Iack
I thought not of them; 'pray thee take them to thee.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I will take thee my little Cupid-whipper.
You muſt not goe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let me alone good Loueall,
Doeſt thou not heare how with an euen gale
That Southweſt winde murmers amongſt the trees?
Within theſe foure and twenty houres I may
Touch on the Belgick ſhore.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: The Belgick ſhore?
What wilt thou doe there man?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'le traile a pike,
Turne Lanceprezado, or Bedee, or any thing
To patch vp a wretched life.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: You'l turne a coxcombe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I neuer ſhall endure to liue a husband
The very name of wife will turne my ſtomack.
I ſhall haue threeſcore vomits in a day.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What wilt thou ſay now Anteros if I ſet thee
As free from this ſame marriage, as the childe
Which ten moneths ſince was but an Embryo?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou canſt not.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I can doe it, feare it not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou canſt nor man, 'tis paſt recouery.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What wilt thou giue me if I doe effect it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Giue thee? I'le ſacrifice my ſelfe vnto thee
My Iupiter, build vp a Temple for thee
Shall take the heauens from Atlas ſhoulders, and
Giue him a Iubile for euer—Speake.
Hee ſhall be at leaſure all the reſt of's life,
For to catch Butterflies— But you doe mock mee,
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But ſtay.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Doe but effect it Iack.
And I will ſtraight make warre vpon the Turke,
Giue thee his Diademe and Scepter — Speake.
The Perſian ſhall be the Maſter of thy Horſe,
The Germane I will make thy cup-bearer.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he. And ſo I ſhall haue all my drink drunk vp,
Thank you for that.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay wilt thou ſpeake, or elſe
Let me be gone. — The Dukes of Italy
Shall be thy footboyes.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Here's a braue promiſer!
Why this out does the Court; but do'ſt thou heare?
How wilt thou doe all this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay 'troth I know not,
But I will doe it, and let that ſuffice.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Well then be ſilent. — Placenta the Shepheards wife
Soone as ſhe heard a marriage was in motion
Betwixt my Kinſwoman and your ſelfe, came running
To me in haſt, and cry'd what doe they meane?
It is not fit, nor can it be (vnleſſe
That they will violate the lawes of Nature)
That Anteros ſhould haue this Gentlewoman;
I aske the cauſe, the Midwife anſwereth
Becauſe ſhe is his Siſter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How? my Siſter?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: And is it poſſible that this is true?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Nay wil you heare with patience?
Or elſe—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: as ſilent as a midnight minute,
Or elſe a Counſellour without a fee,
I'le ſtand and heare, and ſuck it in, and —

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Yet?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'ue done.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Then heare; it ſeem's that Dorothaea
My Vncles wife, ſome ſeuenteene yeares agoe
Suppoſing ſhee had beene with childe, prouided
Such neceſſaries for her, as a woman
That is in her eſtate might ſtand in neede of;
'Twas fam'd about the Country: but at laſt
She found her ſelfe deluded by a tympany,
But fearing leſt ſhe ſhould prove the table talke o'th countrey,
Takes counſell with Placenta for to faigne
A birth, and to that ende employeth her
(Being a Midwife) to procure for money,
The Childe of ſome poore woman new deliver'd.
At the ſame time it fortun'd Anteros
That your mother cryed for Innos helpe,
Which ſhe obtayned, and was deliver'd
Of this your Siſter, whom when ſhe perceiv'd
To be deformed, and diſtort; at length
She was or'ecome by th' Midwife for to part
With her new purchac'd Infant, t'was agreed,
And the birth ſtraight given out to be abortive,
And which is more, beleev'd, and for to colour
The matter o're the better, they did bury
An empty coffin. In the meane time your ſiſter
Was ſecretly convey'd vnto my Aunt,
VVho preſently did faigne to be in travaile,
And was deliver'd in conceit of Her,
VVho but a while agoe vvas call'd your wife.
T'was not long after, but the brace of mothers
Did travaile both together to the dead,
And left my vncle a ſuppoſed daughter.
You have the hiſtory.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And with it heaven,
And immortality: O Loveall, Loveall;
By all the Deityes I could embrace thee
For this thy happy newes, wer't thou a vvoman.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: But whats become of all your promiſes?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O tis a taſte, a ſpice of greatneſſe, Iacke,
To promiſe.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: And to performe iuſt nothing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You doe not heare me ſay ſo. VVhat's the matter?

div.head: ACTVS 5. SCENA 9.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: But ſee the wooers are diſcarded quite
My vncle beates them out of doores.

sp.speaker: Hook.
sp.l: You villaines—
Out of my houſe yee brood of caterpillers.—
Sonne of a hedge and Moone-ſhine; goe—fy, fy, fy.
O miſery beyond— come out you raſcall,
And bring your piping noſe along with you; —
A fire upon this hollow ruffe of yours,
'Tis like your heart—out rogues, and ruffians—
O I am undone.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he. Loveall, theſe men are mine;
I am the Patron of the living now,
Doſt thou ſee this?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I heard as much within.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will behave myſelfe moſt ſcurvily,
Like to ſome ſurly crabbed Patron now,
That has ſome 6, or 7 tyr'd horſes tyed
At • dore. How now?

div.stage: He ſalutes Anteros winking, He in the meane time cuts away the blacke box that hung at his girdle.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What ſayes my Client?
Loveall, I pray thee catechize this box,
Ther's good ſtuffe in 't I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Zea.
sp.l: Good Patron.

sp.speaker: Arthur.
sp.l: Heare me Sir, I'le diſpatch it in three words,
This is a tedious Aſſe, and readeth nought
But Engliſh Treatiſes.

sp.speaker: Zea.
sp.l: Sir, will it pleaſe you
To take particular notice?—

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: But Patron—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who! now the ſent growes hot, 'tis ranck,
The game's in view. Haup,—rate them there—no more
You Sir, that are the ring-leader of this rout.—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Sdeath! what a pack of rogues
Are got together here? what is your name?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Zealous Knowlittle? good;
Of which Vniverſitie?

sp.speaker: Zeal.
sp.l: Of both the Vniverſities.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A very likely thing: good Mr Knowlittle
Separate your ſelfe a little from the people.

sp.speaker: Zeal.
sp.l: With all my heart, I'le ſeparate.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your name?

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.l: My name is Tempest Allmouth ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How? Tempeſt Almouth? where are thy braines man?

sp.speaker: Arth.
sp.l: He has not any.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Beare him company.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: What haue we here? Item, to ſend forth tickets
To all the Brethren that doe inhabite
Within this Shire, to giue them intimation,

l.hi: That M. Mother-tongue ſtands the first of Iune.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You that are next him?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Arthur Armeſtrong ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You there Colloſſe?

sp.speaker: Stutch:
sp.l: My name is Stutchell Legg.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Troth, and thou art well underlay'd indeed,
A couple of foot-ball players I warrant them.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Item: — a pox upon't, here's bawdery,
Ile rake noe deeper in this puddle. — ſo.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: And what muſt we call you?

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Thou ſhould'ſt be a good fellow by thy name.
Come on; what glorious title I beſeech you
Has bounteous Nature fixt on you: nay open.

sp.speaker: Hugo.
sp.l: My name is Hugo obligation.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: How? Hugo obligation? 'pray thee Loveall
Is not this ſhorne bearde villaine the preciſe Scriveneur,
Would faine turne Prieſt?

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: The very ſame I take it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Meddle not with me

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.l: Nay doe not hold me.
A whoreſon Inkebottle, and two skins of parchment, He drawes his Sworde.
Dares he hope for my ſiſter, and a living?
You ſlave, are Parſonages in this age ſo cheape?

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: 'Pray thee Anteros.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Doe not entreat me Loveall,
He dyes: this hat is not more mortified.

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: 'Pray thee be quiet.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Hang him, a death's too good
For ſuch a raſcall. — Sirrah, 'le cut indentur's
Vpon your skin. And here's another Villayne,
Whoſe very countenance ſpeakes Servingman,
Filpot come hither.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Nay but Anteros.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Death man! our Vniverſities doe ſwarme,
They have more Schollers then they know to ſpend
While they are Sweet: and muſt ſuch Rogues as theſe,
Whoſe height of knowledge, is to ſpit and ſnuffle,
And talke ſome 3. houres non-ſenſe, ſhoulder them
Out of their places? what is 't that makes ſo many
Of our quick witt's turne Ieſuits, and forſake
Both their Religion, and their Country thinke you?
Sirrah noe more then thus, lye and thou dyeſt.
Have not you beene a Serving man ſometimes?

sp.speaker: Gan:
sp.l: Yes truely ſir, I'le not deny't, I was
A gentlemans butler once.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: I told you ſo.
The very chipping's hang in's eye-brow's ſtill.
His face unto this inſtant minute ſhines
With broken beere that was his fees, ſtand by,
And doe not hope ſo large a benefit
From me as to be kill'd, live, live, unhappy.
You M. know little know you whoſe box is this?

sp.speaker: Zeal:
sp.l: Truely 'tis mine, verily.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Away you ſtinkards,
I wilbe viſited no more to day.
Avoyde I ſay. Have I not done it well? Exeunt Suitors.

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: Oh noe, you want the pawles, and the hums,
And the grave thumbe under the girdle too.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Oh, that's for old living brokers, I'me a young one.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: You muſt indent then with them, for to keepe you
Some hounds or cocks, and get a handſome wife
To entertaine you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A wife? a thunderbolt
Is entred me, 'pray thee no more.

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: How now?

div.head: ACTVS 5. SCENA 10.
div.stage: Iuſtice Hooke, Terpander, Miſtris Vrſly, Loveall, Anteros, Placenta, Neander, Conſtantina (as dead,) brought in by two of Lively's ſervants, three Fidlers, one of them carryes all the fidles, and Neanders ſword, the other two leade him in.

sp.speaker: Hooke.
sp.l: And get you packing too, thou olde impoſtor,
With your diſtorted puppet here; and you
That make the cuſtardes quake where ere you come,
Thou enemy to ſweet meats.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Mr. Hooke
'Twould relliſh more of wiſedome if you did
Beare out this matter coolely. Come my daughter.

sp.speaker: Hook.
sp.l: O me! the very boy's will laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Anteros ſalute your ſiſter, and embrace her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am undone againe! what ſhall I doe

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What ſhall you doe? why kiſſe her man.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Siſter god ſave you, — and as much to you
My never-to-be-hereafter father in law.

sp.speaker: Hook:
sp.l: Woe's me! what ſhall I ſay? what ſhall I doe?
I have given in the morgage, and without money.
But what new ſpectacle is this?

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: Whats heere?
How? the dead body of a gentle-woman?

sp.speaker: Pla:
sp.l: Is this Neandur?

sp.speaker: 1 Rust.
sp.l: Hold the cut throat fidlers
Whilſt we doe bring this gentlewoman 'fore the juſtice.

sp.speaker: 2 Rust:
sp.l: A kind and loving husband ſure, that has.
Made a fayre hand on's wife thus the firſt day.

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: Ha? what is this I ſee? O trayterous eyes:
Can I believe ye any more? my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Hook:
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Pla:
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Lou:
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe. O partiall heavens! but yet it is not,
'Tis not long ſince I left my ſiſter ſafe
With in her chamber, and in another habit —
By all the powers 'tis ſhe — I doe profane
The god's; it is not ſhe, it is not. — once more.
The twins of Leda were not halfe ſo like.
I'le be reſolv'd immediatly.

sp.speaker: 1 Rust:
sp.l: Good M. juſtice, Exit.
I pray you heare me. As we did daunce even now
In your North field, we found this gentlewoman,
Lying all along (as to ſay) even quite dead,
And this her husband with his naked ſword
Standing hard by her.

sp.speaker: Hook:
sp.l: Another riddle yet.
Her husband? ha? Why is not this Neander
One of the rivall's in my daughters love?

sp.speaker: 2 Rust.
sp.l: Ander, or Pander, wee know not that,
But 'tis her husband, that wee'r ſure of
Is he not Robbin?

sp.speaker: 1 Rust.
sp.l: I that he is our Edward,
We both were preſent when they were detracted.

sp.speaker: 2 Ruſt.
sp.l: Subtracted you foole. But as I ſayd before
Seeing him ſtand ſo deſperatly with his ſword
We ſtole behind him, and ſo caught him.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: A valiant act believ't. Good ſir, let's goe.

sp.speaker: Pla:
sp.l: Ah Conſtantina, ah good heart! was this
The journey you intended?

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Sir, I beſeech you —
We ſhall be poyſon'd with theſe womens ſighs He offers to goe.
'Tis worſe then a Germayne hot-houſe.

sp.speaker: Ter:
sp.l: Stay, we will ſee the end of this.

sp.speaker: Hook:
sp.l: Fye, fye, Hell is broke looſe upon me: all her furies
Are come at once t'aſſault me.

sp.speaker: Con:
sp.l: Ah Cleopes! ſhe revives

sp.speaker: Nean:
sp.l: She lives againe, O miracle of women!

sp.speaker: Con:
sp.l: Where art thou Cleopes?

sp.speaker: Nean:
sp.l: Oh hated name,
Enough t'infect the world, but that it comes
Out of thoſe lipps.

sp.speaker: Pla:
sp.l: Speake Conſtantina.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What haue I to doe
With light or heaven? I will not live.

sp.speaker: Pla:
sp.l: O me!
Shee ſwounds againe.

sp.speaker: 1 Ruſt.
sp.l: Why doe you rub her head
And face ſo much, you fooliſh woman you?
Let me alone, I'le find her wound I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Forbeare, or I'le find that ſwines face of yours.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I am too bad for hell, they'l not receiue me,
They are afraid I ſhould infect thoſe ſoules,
Thoſe vertuous ſoules which doe inhabit there.

sp.speaker: Nean
sp.l: Art thou not ſoftned yet Neander? Ha?
Hadſt thou an heart cut out 'oth Diamond rocke,
Sure this would melt it.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: O my Cleopes!

sp.speaker: 1 Ruſt.
sp.l: What will you giue ſir, and I will let you
Shift for your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: What thou deſerveſt villaine.

sp.speaker: 2 Rust.
sp.l: Halfe part, or elſe ſhe ſhall not go.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Take halfe.
sp.stage: He breakes looſe, and beats them out.
sp.l: I will divide my gifts betwixt yee — there.
Thou Temple of Vertue, fayreſt Conſtantina. —

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Oh I ſhall die againe if I ſee him.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: But will you liue if I doe preſently
Make a divorce betwixt you and Neander?
And place you in the armes of him you ſo
Loue, and adore, your Cleopes?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: You cannot.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Thou'rt all divinitie, indeed I cannot.
See where Pandora comes; but now I can.
Behold my Lucius.

div.head: ACT. 5. SCE. 11.
div.stage: Laurentio, Lucius, Endymion, Pandora, Iſabella, cum caeteris.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Nay, I will ſtill perſiſt to follow thee
Baſeſt of men.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Good father.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Suffer him;
His tongue has learn'd the palſie from his hands;
Alas hee's old, and muſt bee pardon'd for't.
But what imports this multitude? and ſee Neander
With his Boy-bride. Pandora, ſweeteſt Lady —

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: An other tempeſt! where ſhall I ſhelter me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: By all the joyes in Loue, by all the ſorrowes,
By all his Roſes, and his Worme-wood, take
Thy thoughts from me, and let them doubled fall
Vpon my friend Neander. —Faireſt foule,
Doe but contemplate that moſt curious frame
Of man, in what a pleaſing harmonie
Nature has marryed all thoſe provinces
His limbes together: view but his ſparkling eye,
And reade divinitie there; looke on his hayre,
Survey his face, and fee how Majeſtie
And ſweetneſſe there doe ſtriue for victory,
And ſtill the iſſue's doubtfull.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not overcome; diſguiſe farewell.
O thou that art the ſhame of all thy ſexe,
Faire Constantina, yet not halfe ſo faire
As vertuous, here behold thy Cleopes;
Neander's vaniſh'd; why doe you wonder ſo?
I doe confeſſe I lou'd that Gentlewoman,
And for her loue I tooke on this diſguiſe,
And here for thine I put it off againe,
And on my bended knee doe begg my pardon
For all the wrong I'ue done thee

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: It is a miracle: but the bonds, the living.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: O heavens! 'tis he, moſt happy Conſtantina!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: My Cleopes? grant me ſome reſpite joy
Before thou kilſt me — Oh my Cleopes!
Whom doe I embrace? into whoſe armes am I fallen?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O conſtant virgin!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: But how ſhall I hereafter
Giue any credit to my ſenſes? O
Placenta, courteous Midwife, pray thee tell mee,
Where am I now? in heaven?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Bridle your paſſion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Am I my ſelfe? or doe I dreame all this?

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Lucius, take truce with wonder, I am Cleopes,
And I doe hope though now I weare that name,
As deare to thee as when I heard Neander.
You may remember when as firſt the beautie
Of fayre Pandora did attract your eyes
To wonder, and to loue, that I was then
A buſie wooer unto Constantina:
But ſo it pleaſed Cupid, that while I
Drew out a languiſhing and luke-warme ſuit
To her, the vigour of Pandora's beames,
(As doth the Sun unto our culinar fire)
Did quite extinguiſh that ſame petty flame.
Thinking it vaine t'attempt her in that ſhape,
I preſently did take ſome diſcontent,
And fain'd a journey into Belgia,
And not long after tooke on this diſguiſe,
And return'd hither; where I haue remain'd
Your Rivall, and capitall friend together:
And (which I wonder at the moſt) unknowne:
You haue my Metamorphoſis. But ſweet,
How cam'ſt thou 'pray thee, unto Mr Liuely?
And by what trickes did he inveagle thee
Vnto this contract, ſince thou didſt not know
That Cleopes was there inviſible?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My better Genius, you ſhall heare within
The ſtory whole, it is too tedious
To be told here.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: But now Pandora, why
Stand you ſo dully here, and doe not flie
Into his ſtrict embraces, who alone
Loues you, and who alone deſerues your loue?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Doe I loue her? doe I deſerue her loue?
Haſt thou (ſweet friend) for me forſaken her,
Whom thou didſt prize 'boue thine owne proper ſoule?
And now haſt married her whom thou didſt flie?
And all for my ſake, and ſhall I thus repay thee?
But for her loue thou ne're hadſt been Neander;
And but for mine hadſt been Neander ſtill;
Friend Cleopes, or if thou wilt Neander,
(Vnder both titles moſt belov'd of me)
Was ſhee all Venus; did each hayre of hers
Fetter a Loue, were there as many Cupids
That hover'd o'e her head, as there be lights
VVhich guild yon Marble roofe, by them I ſweare,
By all that's Sacred, by what ever flyes
The touch of mortall eye, I ſweare againe,
I would diſclaime her and her loue for ever.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Troth Lucius, I doe pitie you, that do •
Spend ſo much breath unto ſo little end,
VVhat need all theſe deepe proteſtations?
I care not this for all your loue, nor yet
For your friend Ianus there with the two faces;
Nor do I think ye men.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: So quickly?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Yes.
I doe confeſſe I am a woman; ſee,
Here is the man has wonne what ye haue loſt;
Stout ſouldiers ſure, that when the Citie gates
VVere open to yee, durſt not enter in.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O Iſabella, 'tis for thy ſake I know
That all theſe miſeries doe happen mee.
(Forgiue mee good Laurentio) Iſabella,
At length I haue experience what it is
To loue an outſide, the meere barke of woman,
And to forſake an inward vertue: but
If once I haue thee in poſſeſſion more —

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: Follow mee Witch, devill, ſtrumpet, proſtitute.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Ah whither will he drag mee? oh my heart!

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: What haue yee done with my dead ſiſters body?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Thy ſiſters body now has got a ſoule.
(O my ſweet Cleopes!) moſt welcome brother.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: But doth ſhe liue then?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: And ſo happily,
As I haue call'd it impudence to wiſh
What I doe now enjoy.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Whom doe I ſee?
My daughter Iſabella?

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: But is this Cleopes?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I dare not looke upon that wronged face.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: It is, and now thy ſiſters husband.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Brother,
All health, all happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: More then all to you,
Good Cleopes.— But doſt thou liue, my ſiſter?
Why waſt thou dead but now?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt heare that
Some other time.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Seeſt thou that virgin?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Yes, it is my ſiſter Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I am undone! my father, and my brother.
Sir, I beſeech you pardon what my loue,
And younger yeeres haue treſpas'd.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Riſe my daughter;
Ioy will not ſuffer mee for to be angry.
Seeſt thou that face?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: It is Endymion
My brother.—Brother, God ſaue you.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Siſter!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Thy Brother? 'tis thy traytour that I meane,
That has undone thee and thy name.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: 'Tis Lucius.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir I beſeech you doe not hearken to him.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A pox upon this honeſty,
It will vndoe us all: 'tis ten to one
But that his tender Conſcience will perſwade him
To pay in the money for all this.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Faire ſoule
Canſt thou forgiue thy Lucius?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.l: Canſt thou loue
Thy Iſabella?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Give me a man dares aske
That queſtion? Good Laurentio let me craue
Your likeing and conſent.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Conſent? to what?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To marry this your daughter.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Marry my daughter?
No periur'd wretch.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.l: Sir I beſeech you grant it.
O Lucius! O happy houre!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Thou haſt her,
And with her ſuch a portion as ſhall pleaſe thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I will not heare of Portion, ſhee her ſelfe
Is dowry enough to mee.— O Iſabella!

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: What? Is the Players boy prov'd woman too?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: Hook.
sp.l: I ſay trouble me not—the morgage.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir I beſeech you heare me.

sp.speaker: Hook.
sp.l: Fy, fy, fy.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And let me haue your approbation▪
In this young Gentleman for my husband.

sp.speaker: Hook.
sp.l: O.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Perhaps ſir you may doubt of his eſtate,
But if you'le credit me, I can inſtruct you,
I am his Father, hee mine onely Sonne,
And (I doe thanke my ſtarrs) our fortun's are
None of the meaneſt. Speake Sir, will you give
Your daughter here, without a portion?

sp.speaker: Hook.
sp.l: Without a Portion? take her what er'e thou art
So, So, that care is paſt yet, this a little
Help's out with th' other loſſes.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Maſter Hooke,
You ſhall not frowne, ſince all things here doe ſmile;
To morrow I will pay you halfe your mony,
So you will grant me a generall acquittance;
'Tis in my power (you know) and I may chuſe
Whether I'le pay a farthing, but no more,
(There is a thing call'd conſcience within me;
And) you ſhall have it: therefore be frolike Sir.

sp.speaker: Hook.
sp.l: Thou art an honeſt man. Yee are all honeſt, yee are all honeſt.

stage.hi: Enter Liuely having heard the other Scene.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: All this while have I
Employ'd mine cares about this buſineſſe.
Now ſhow thy ſelfe, and of what houſe thou com'ſt.
All health to this faire company—much ioy—
Much happineſſe — and a young Sonne to you;
Are you at leaſure for to kill me yet?
You ſee I'me come againe.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Let me embrace thee
Thou inſtrument of all our good.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: Yes, yes,
I was a foole, knewe nothing, knewe iuſt nothing,
Could not divine a whit, not tell, not tell,
How this ſame geare would come to paſſe, not I;
How doe you like your Liuely now? your Liuely?

sp.speaker: Hooke
sp.l: Wee will diſcourſe of that within. Terpander,
Sir will it pleaſe you follow? you my Sonne,
Gentl'men y'are all my gueſts to night. Mee
Think's I am growne Peſtilent kinde vpon the ſuddayne,
The Muſicke too, wee will be merry, come,
Nay come, come, take me while the homours hot.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Loueall, a word: nay troupe on, let them troupe.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: The newes?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Faith nothing but to take my leaue,
Bid you far well.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Why ſo? I pray thee ſtay,
You'le in I hope.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What among ſuch a kennell
Of women? noe, adiew.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Nay preethee goe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not for the Fay'ry Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Wiſe.
sp.l: Mr. Loveall,
Sweet Mr. Loveall.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: As I am a gentleman, and an elder brother, I am almoſt choak'd.

sp.speaker: Wiſe.
sp.l: Sweet Mr. Loveall, O Mr. Loveall. 'Tis vtterly againſt my complexion,
To lye here any longer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Death! our fooles,
Our diſh of buffles: as I hope to proſper
My thoughts had loſt them quite.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I thought not of them.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.l: Good Mr. Loveall are the officers gone?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Anteros, Anteros, is the coaſt cleare yet?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But how ſhall wee diſpoſe of them?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Wee'd beſt
Barrell them vp and ſend them for new England.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A pox there's fooles enow already there.
Let's pickle them for winter Sallads.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: No;
They are not capable of Salt, man; rather
Let's get ſome broaken trumpet, or old drumme,
And ſhew them to the people from ſome ſtrange
Beaſts out of Affrick

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Father, my gowne is not ſilke yet.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: A bots on you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Harke, there's another egge ſprung, my ſheepheard and his faire daughter.

sp.speaker: Wiſe.
sp.l: Loveall, Mr. Loveall, I am of a ſanguine complexion.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now all the world! what ſhall wee do with them?
But ſtay, a word,—performe it, I'le take order [Hee whiſpers with Loveall]
T' vncaſe vm' to your hands.—
Now quickly Nodle, all is quiet now,— Exit Loveall.
Come Mr. William — Not a mouſe is ſtirring—
Safe, ſafe, all 's ſafe. Ha, he, he.

div.stage: [They all 4 come out at the 4 corners of the ſtage.]

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.l: I'ue ſpoyl'd my cloathes quite, would I had a bruſh;
How now? wee're gull'd.

sp.speaker: Wiſ.
sp.l: I, as I am a liuing ſaule. — marke the end on't.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Who haue wee here? does his ghoſt walke?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.l: Wee are all gee • 'd I perceiue it plaine now.

sp.speaker: Wiſ.
sp.p: Who's that? Mr. Mungrell? is the Scholler aliue againe? I ſhould haue beene very melancholy to haue beene hang'd as I am a liuing ſaule.

sp.speaker: Nod
sp.l: If I could get my raepier and a bruſh, [Redit in ſcenam Loveall & Placenta with a cudgell.]
I'de ſteale away.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Would you haue a bruſh? I'le bruſh yee yee villaines,
Nay, Mr. Loueall told me what duſty companions yee were,
And that yee wanted bruſhing, and how yee bad
Abus'd my husband, and my daughter, ty'de them
To a tree, come one your wayes, want yee bruſhing?

Ye raſcalls, I'le bruſh you, would ye be bruſht▪
She beats thē forth

Come on, lets ſee what cover'd diſh
• 'haue here now? She vnties them
Hy day! you lubberly knaue; what Madame Gillian too?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: What? is ſhee come now to trouble vs!
My daughter, I doe charge you on my bleſſing
Looke ſcuruily vpon her.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes forſooth Father.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: Call her not Mother darling, but diſclaime her,
Shee is no wife of mine, ſhee does conſpire
Againſt our gentility daughter, and ſhee lyes;
Call her the plaine old woman, ſweet-lips, doe;
Ile beare you cut in't, doe as your father bids you.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But forſooth father, my neckercher is not turn'd into Gold yet.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: They are both mad of a certaine.

sp.speaker: Stip,
sp.p: I am a gentleman, and I will be a gentleman, I will encloſe, and I will rayſe rents—I wil be a lower-houſe man, and I will be—

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: An old cox-combe, and you ſhall be beaten. [She beats him.]

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: But does this ſtand good in law?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: Feare not that; I'le find an old ſtatute for it, doubt it not. You are a gentleman? and you will be a gentleman? I'le make you gentle enough e're I haue done with you.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: O, O, O.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: And you my ſweet lips that wil not call me mother, but looke ſcuruily,
Come on your wayes I haue the common law on my ſide too for this. [She beats Merda.]

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Oh mother, I'le neuer bee a gentlewoman more while I liue, nor neuer talke of gold neckerchers, no that I won't truely.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: Yes, you ſhall bee a Lower-houſe man, you ſhall; I'le take you downe a Pinne, you'r too high now.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: O, O, good wife—O, O, hony wife.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: You'l in? [Exit. Plac. & Merda.]

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Buz, peace and catch a mouſe cry I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What is my Scholler return'd? pre'thee goe in Iack Loveall, I'le change but two words with him Exit Love. And follow. Well ſayd, nay looke not ſowerly on the matter.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: You haue abus'd mee Sir, and goe to the fence Schoole with mee if you dare, or elſe wr • ſtle a fall with me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He giue thee ſatisfaction my rowſer
My Hit-her better, nay put off theſe frownes;
What ſay'ſt thou to my ſiſter, and the Living?
I know you haue heard the newes from out the Cabbin,
And you was once a Suitour to her; ſpeake,
Will that content thee? come you are not the firſt
Has got a Parſonage with fooling Sir,
I will procure it for thee, feare it not:
Nay ſpare your Hatt, it will be tedious,
My thankes ſhall be in Oates.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: But Maſter Ieoffry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Follow Iack Loveall in. [Exit Ham.]

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: You know I was your Maſter to day.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well put the caſe.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Poore, and ill parell'd.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: But now you ſee how ſtrangely altered.

p.hi: Put the caſe the third time.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Are you avis'd of that? I'le n'ere truſt winking beaſt againe for your ſake, I'le tell you but ſo. Did you not tell mee that Obrum would make me a gentleman? Obrum? Obrum? if Obrum has no better tricks then theſe, let Obrum keepe his tricks to coole his porredge, 'sduds I look'd euery minute when Obrum would haue put a greene ſcarlet ſuite vpon my backe like your's, all to bee dawb'd with ſpingle ſpangles; and in the meane time comes my wife with a blacke and blew home ſpun of her owne making. Well that ſame Obrum is a ſembling cony catching knaue, and I know what I could call you too, but for your whiniard, and your ſtaring goggles.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stipes, no more, advaunce thy duller eye,
Know'ſt thou what all thoſe blazing ſtars portend?

sp.speaker: Sti.
sp.p: I, I, by'r Lady? how now? 'sduds I thinke fourty Obrums haue beene here, (Maſter Ieoffry is that Obrum that makes gentlefolkes, a Taylor?) one Obrum could neuer haue paynted them thus.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: PEace prophane rudeneſſe; what alteration's this?
What meane theſe bended Knees? but are theſe women?
Am • a Conuert then? ſo ſuddainely?
Surely ſome Power greater then all that Sex
Is interpos'd, vayl'd in a femall outſide,
Elſe how come I ſo ſupple ioynted, that
Before was ſtiffer then the Rhodian Statue?
There is an Homage due, and I muſt pay't
Spite of my proudeſt nerues. Moſt Sacred Goddeſſe,
Behold a Penitent, that falls thus lowe
Before your feete: as you haue ſhowne your ſelfe
More then a Mortall, in converting me,
Confirme it by your Pardon; 'tis a Vertue
No leſſe deſeruing, and as neere to miracle.
And You great Monarch, that the world may know
How nigh a Kin to heauen and all the Gods
You are in bloud and power, confute that bold
Erronious tenent, prooue the Age of Wonders
Still to endure. What I have promiſed
Vnto this Shepheard (as a miracle)
To be perform'd by Obron and this tree,
Doe you effect; make vs all gentlemen.
Which one Kinde ray ſent from Your gracious eyes
Will doe, and in that confidence wee riſe.
